Housing assistance programs for those affected by COVID-19 are available. Find information on rental assistance and mortgage assistance.

questionOriginal: Is it safe to go grocery shopping?
questionText: Is it safe to go grocery shopping?
answerOriginal:
Currently there is no evidence to show that the COVID-19 virus is spread through food or food packaging. However, there is concern about being able to keep at least 6 feet away from other shoppers and to reduce your risk of getting sick while getting groceries.

The Vermont Retail & Grocers Association has a regularly updated list of what services Vermont retailers and grocers are offering during the COVID-19 pandemic. These services range from limited delivery, to curbside pickup and designated shopping hours for vulnerable populations.

Anyone who is sick or thinks they might be sick should stay home. Ask a family member, friend or neighbor to help you get your groceries, or see about having food delivered.

When you leave the store, you should wash your hands or use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Read more about shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the Food and Drug Administration.
answerText:
Currently, there is no evidence to show that the COVID-19 virus is spread through food or food packaging. Follow these precautions to help keep the virus from spreading and to protect yourself while you shop:

Stay home if you are sick. Ask a family member, friend or neighbor to help you get your groceries, or have food or groceries delivered.
Wear a face mask or covering while youâre in the store.
Keep a 6-foot distance from people you don't live with whenever possible. Follow any arrows on the floor or other signage that directs how people should move through the store.
Use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol after you leave the store. Wash your hands with soap and water when you return home and after you put away your groceries.

Read more about shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the Food and Drug Administration.

questionOriginal: What do I need to know before I have an outpatient or inpatient procedure?
questionText: What do I need to know before I have an outpatient or inpatient procedure?
answerOriginal: If you are scheduled for an outpatient (or inpatient) procedure, you may need to be tested for COVID-19. The health care provider doing the procedure will test you no more than 7 days before the procedure. You must self-isolate until the test and the procedure. You will receive your test results from your health care provider before the procedure.
answerText: If you are scheduled for an outpatient (or inpatient) procedure, you may need to be tested for COVID-19. The health care provider doing the procedure will test you no more than 7 days before the procedure. You must self-isolate until the test and the procedure. You will receive your test results from your health care provider before the procedure.

questionOriginal: Can I get COVID-19 from my pets or other animals? Can animals carry the virus on their skin or fur?
questionText: Can I get COVID-19 from my pets or other animals? Can animals carry the virus on their skin or fur?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC, at this time, there is no evidence that animals play a large role in spreading the virus that causes COVID-19, and no evidence that the COVID-19 virus can spread to people from the skin, fur or hair of pets. Based on the limited information available at this time, the risk of animals spreading COVID-19 to people is considered to be low. A small number of pets have been reported to be infected with the virus that causes COVID-19, mostly after contact with people with COVID-19.

Pets have other types of coronaviruses that can make them sick, like canine and feline coronaviruses. These other coronaviruses cannot infect people and are not related to the current COVID-19 pandemic.

However, since animals can spread other diseases to people, itâs always a good idea to practice healthy habits around pets and other animals, such as washing your hands and maintaining good hygiene. Find more information on staying safe and healthy around animals including pets from the CDC.

Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.
answerText:
According to the CDC and based on the limited information available to date, the risk of animals spreading COVID-19 to people is low. There is no evidence that the COVID-19 virus can spread to people from the skin, fur or hair of pets.
However, because animals can sometimes carry other germs that can make people sick, itâs always a good idea to practice healthy habits around pets and other animals, such as washing your hands before and after interacting with them.
Learn more about what to do if you have pets and answers to frequently asked questions about pets and animals from the CDC.
Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

questionOriginal: Can sunlight disinfect surfaces?
questionText: Can sunlight disinfect surfaces?
answerOriginal: We donât know yet. According to the CDC, early scientific data suggest the COVID-19 virus can be killed by the sunâs ultraviolet (UV) light. However, the ability of the sunâs UV light to kill the virus on surfaces needs more research. Factors â such as cloudiness, latitude (distance from the equator), time of day, and amount of time exposed to the sunâs UV light â determine how effectively the virus is killed.
answerText: We donât know yet. According to the CDC, early scientific data suggest the COVID-19 virus can be killed by the sunâs ultraviolet (UV) light. However, the ability of the sunâs UV light to kill the virus on surfaces needs more research. Factors â such as cloudiness, latitude (distance from the equator), time of day, and amount of time exposed to the sunâs UV light â determine how effectively the virus is killed.

questionOriginal: How can I tell if Iâm sick with COVID-19 or something else?
questionText: How can I tell if Iâm sick with COVID-19 or something else?
answerOriginal:
Sometimes you may be having symptoms of COVID-19 but are sick with something else. Talk to your health care provider about your symptoms and whether you should be tested for COVID-19. You can also check your symptoms on this chart of COVID-19 symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.

If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.

questionOriginal: Are syringe service programs (needle exchanges) still open?
questionText: Are syringe service programs (needle exchanges) still open?
answerOriginal:
Yes, services have been changed to limit in-person contact. Some services may not be available like walk-in HIV/Hepatitis C testing. Find a syringe service program near you.

Call VT Helplink for free, confidential alcohol and drug support and referral services at 802-565-LINK or search for a syringe service program.
answerText:

Find a syringe service program near you.
You can also call VT Helplink for free, confidential alcohol and drug support and referrals at 802-565-LINK or search for a syringe service program.

questionOriginal: How can I be safer when using drugs?
questionText: How can I be safer when using drugs?

Syringe service programs have supplies and information to help keep you safe. Their services are anonymous and free. Find a syringe service program near you and give them a call.

For more information, read the Harm Reduction Coalitionâs guidance for people who use drugs and harm reduction programs.

You can also call VT Helplink for free, confidential alcohol and drug support and referrals at 802-565-LINK or search for a syringe service program.

questionOriginal: Is there temporary housing available if I might have or have tested positive for COVID-19?
questionText: Is there temporary housing available if I might have or have tested positive for COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
There is temporary housing available â commonly referred to as the motel voucher program â for people experiencing homelessness who are suspected to have or tested positive for COVID-19 and donât require hospitalization.

Call the Vermont Economic Services Division at 1-800-479-6151 Monday through Thursday from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. and Friday from 8 a.m. to 4:15 p.m. After hours, you can call 2-1-1.

If you need to isolate or quarantine due to COVID-19 and donât have a suitable home environment, there is temporary housing available. Learn more about isolation/quarantine and recovery housing sites.

questionOriginal: Can the COVID-19 virus spread through pools and hot tubs?
questionText: Can the COVID-19 virus spread through pools and hot tubs?
answerOriginal:
There is no evidence that COVID-19 can be spread to humans through the use of pools and hot tubs. Proper operation, maintenance, and disinfection (for example, with chlorine and bromine) of pools and hot tubs should remove or inactivate the virus that causes COVID-19.

Find more information from the CDC's Water and COVID-19 FAQs.
answerText:
There is no evidence that the virus can spread to people through the use of pools, hot tubs or water playgrounds. Proper operation and disinfection of the water (for example, with chlorine and bromine) should kill the virus.
When youâre at a pool or hot tub, follow these steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask any time youâre not in the water and canât keep 6 feet apart from people you donât live with.

Learn more about healthy swimming, find information for residential pool or hot tub owners, and find more frequently asked questions about pools, hot tubs and water playgrounds from the CDC.

questionOriginal: Can I get COVID-19 from swimming in a lake or river?
questionText: Can I get COVID-19 from swimming in a lake or river?
answerOriginal:
The COVID-19 virus could possibly enter waterways through untreated wastewater that is discharged into waterways following large rain events or for other reasons. The virus has been found in untreated wastewater, but there has been no evidence that a person can get COVID-19 from being exposed to untreated wastewater or sewerage systems.

According to the CDC, it is thought that the COVID-19 virus does not spread through standard municipal and individual septic system wastewater treatment practices. Guidance will be updated if anything new is learned.

The Health Department recommends that towns do routine weekly E. coli testing and after large storm events during the swim season. These tests are a good indication of the water quality, meaning that if the E. coli levels are low, then COVID-19 virus levels are also expected to be low.

The best practices for staying healthy while swimming are to obey signage at beaches, do not swim during and following large rain events, and do not swallow the water.
answerText:
There is no evidence that the COVID-19 virus spreads to people through the water in lakes, oceans, rivers or other natural bodies of water.
The virus has been found in untreated wastewater, which means it could possibly enter lakes or rivers when untreated wastewater is discharged into waterways after rainstorms or for other reasons. According to the CDC, it is currently thought that the risk of getting COVID-19 from properly designed and maintained sewerage systems is low. There has been no evidence that a person can get COVID-19 by swallowing or coming in contact with water contaminated by feces (poop) from an infected person.
The Health Department recommends that towns do routine weekly E. coli testing and after large rainstorms during the swim season. These tests are a good indication of the water quality, meaning that if the E. coli levels are low, then COVID-19 virus levels are also expected to be low.
The best practices for staying healthy while swimming are to obey signage at beaches, do not swim during and following large rainstorms, and do not swallow the water.
When you are at a beach or swimming spot, plan to âarrive, play, and leaveâ â avoiding gathering before and after activities and giving others space. Follow these steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask any time youâre not in the water and canât keep 6 feet apart from people you donât live with.

Learn more about healthy swimming from the CDC.

questionOriginal: How can we safely carpool?
questionText: How can we safely carpool?
answerOriginal:
If possible, donât carpool. This is because people will be within 6 feet of each other and in an enclosed space. If you need to carpool to work, school or sports games or practices, itâs best to:

  • Wear masks at all times.
  • Limit the number of people you carpool with.
  • Carpool with the same people, ideally those who are following the COVID-19 prevention steps in their day-to-day lives.
  • Keep a log of who you and your family have carpooled with that includes dates, names of other riders, and the duration of the ride.
  • Keep the windows or vents open for fresh air.
  • Cover your coughs and sneezes.
  • Clean and disinfect surfaces often.
  • Wash or sanitize your hands before getting in and out of the car.

Do not carpool if you are sick or have been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.

Read the CDCâs tips on carpooling safely.

Wash or sanitize your hands before getting in and out of the car.

Do not carpool if you are sick or have been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.
Read the CDCâs tips on carpooling safely.

questionOriginal: Does smoking or vaping increase the risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19?
questionText: Does smoking or vaping increase the risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
There is growing evidence that e-cigarette use or vaping can harm lung health. The coronavirus attacks the lungs, making it harder for people who smoke or vape â tobacco, cannabis or anything else â to fight off the virus, putting them at much greater risk of severe illness, even death.

802Quits is the Vermont tobacco quit resource. You can get help to quit by phone or online.

By phone, call 1-800-QUIT-NOW for 1:1 coaching, available 24/7, with email and text support.

Online: 802Quits.org

By quitting, youâll also protect people in your household by reducing their exposure to secondhand smoke and aerosol as you spend more time at home right now.
answerText:
People who smoke â tobacco, cannabis or anything else â have an increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19, a disease that attacks the lungs. Vaping damages your lungsâ immune system and is linked to a substantially increased risk of COVID-19 among teenagers and young adults.
802Quits is Vermontâs tobacco quit resource. Help is available online and by phone for Vermonters 13 and older. Call 1-800-QUIT-NOW for one-on-one coaching, available 24/7, with free nicotine replacement therapy, email and text support, or visit 802quits.org for online workshops and customized quit tools.
My Life, My Quit is a free, confidential quit program designed for teens, available by texting âStart My Quitâ to 855-891-9989 or calling to talk with a coach.
By quitting, youâll also protect people in your household by reducing their exposure to the dangerous chemicals in secondhand smoke and aerosol as you spend more time at home during the pandemic.

questionOriginal: Can I travel to or from Canada?
questionText: Can I travel to or from Canada?
answerOriginal: Check the U.S. Customs Border Protection website and the Canadian Border Services Agency for current information about travel to Canada.
answerText:
Check CDCâsÂ travel notices for Canada and read CanadaâsÂ entry restrictions for current information about travel to or from Canada.
Follow the CDCâsÂ after travel guidanceÂ when you return to the U.S. When you return to Vermont, you must quarantine for 14 days. You have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.

questionOriginal: What does social distancing mean?
questionText: What does social distancing mean?
answerOriginal:
Social distancing means maintaining a physical distance (approximately 6 feet or 2 meters) from others you do not live with. This includes when you're inside a store or outside for exercise.

The COVID-19 virus spreads easily from person-to-person. It travels through the air when a sick person coughs, sneezes or talks. One way to contain the spread of COVID-19 is to stop people from sharing it. Without a vaccine or treatment, we can help contain the virus by:

  • Staying at home to protect others if you are sick.

  • Staying home is still the best way to lower our risk of COVID-19, but small groups of 10 or fewer people are now allowed if health and safety precautions are followed. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

  • Continuing to go outside, take walks, do essential errands while maintaining a physical distance from others and practicing proper hygiene. Remember that ticks are active this time of year. Find out how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.

  • Wearing a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain, especially at the grocery store, pharmacy, doctorâs office, hospital or other essential business or office, and on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

  • Washing your hands (adults and children) any time you go inside, before you eat, and before you spend time with people who are more vulnerable to the effects of COVID-19.
answerText:
Social distancing means maintaining a physical distance (at least 6 feet or 2 meters, for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period) from people you do not live with. This includes when youâre inside a store, gathering with friends or family, or outside for exercise or a walk.
The COVID-19 virus is thought to spread mainly throughÂ close contact from person to person, by respiratory droplets when people with COVID-19 cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe.Â A person can be infected and not have any symptoms. In addition to keeping a 6-foot distance from others, these are things you can do to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask when youâre outside and canât keep 6 feet apart or anytime youâre inside with people you donât live with.

Learn more aboutÂ why, how and when to do these things and more about getting together with friends and family.

questionOriginal: Do I need to quarantine if out-of-state visitors are staying in my home?
questionText: Do I need to quarantine if out-of-state visitors are staying in my home?
answerOriginal:
If you are hosting travelers under quarantine in your home or lodging, you do not also need to quarantine. If you are sharing space, stay at least 6 feet from the people under quarantine. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces. Disinfect commonly touched surfaces and check for symptoms for 14 days.

Visitors from counties in New York and New England with low numbers of active infections do not need to quarantine. Read the travel guidance and check the map of approved counties, which is updated weekly.

Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for information for travelers to Vermont. They can get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
answerText:
If you are hosting travelers under quarantine in your home or lodging, you do not also need to quarantine. That means you can go to school, work, or the grocery store. However, you need to stay at least 6 feet from the people who are under quarantine. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with the people who are hosting them. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.
Visitors from certain counties with low rates of active cases (âgreenâ counties) do not need to quarantine.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

questionOriginal: How is Vermont deciding when it is safe to reopen?
questionText: How is Vermont deciding when it is safe to reopen?
answerOriginal:
Most recent modeling data suggests Vermont has reached its peak in the number of new cases of COVID-19, hospital capacity, and the number people who are currently infected with COVID-19.

However, it is important to remember that not everyone infected with the virus has symptoms and there are still many people who are currently infected and could spread it to others.

Vermont is looking at four key measures to inform steps to reopen:

  • Ongoing reduction in cases for at least 14 days
  • A health care system that is safely able to treat all patients without exceeding its capacity or using crisis standards of care
  • The ability to test all people with symptoms
  • Widespread active monitoring of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 and tracing their close contacts

At this time, Vermont continues to do well in keeping the number of cases of COVID-19 down. This is hopeful news. To continue on this path, it is critical that Vermonters continue to follow the general precautions to keep the virus from spreading and to help save lives: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

Read the latest Vermont COVID-19 modeling projections from the Vermont Department of Financial Regulation.

Wear a mask when youâre outside and canât keep 6 feet apart or anytime youâre inside with people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.
Read the latest Vermont COVID-19 modeling projections from the Vermont Department of Financial Regulation.

questionOriginal: What are some ways I can talk about my COVID-19 "comfort level" when making plans with friends and family?
questionText: What are some ways I can talk about my COVID-19 "comfort level" when making plans with friends and family?
answerOriginal:
As life picks up again, we are learning there is a lot to discuss before seeing friends and family to feel comfortable and stay safe. Here are four tips to help have the âCOVID Talkâ â a conversation to negotiate boundaries and establish expectations ahead of time.

  1. Ask questions. Before you get together, start with an open and honest conversation about what everyone has been doing to stay healthy and how they have been socializing. Consider everyoneâs worries, boundaries and possible COVID-19 exposure risk so you can all get on the same page.
  2. Focus on what you need. Using âIâ instead of âyouâ statements helps people avoid feeling defensive or judged. In fact, blaming and shaming may actually increase push back and the likelihood of risk-taking behaviors. We recommend sharing what youâre comfortable with based on your own perspective instead of making demands of others.
  3. Share why it is important to you. Share what level of risk works for you and why. It might be different for others. Some people feel comfortable taking on a moderate amount of risk in their lives. Others may not feel comfortable taking on any risk. Focusing on your own reasons for staying safe can help people to better understand and get on board.
  4. Set boundaries and stick to them. We are all for keeping it friendly, open and non-judgmental â but that doesnât mean you have to skimp on your safety! Itâs OK to be clear and straightforward with what you need to feel safe and comfortable. Itâs also okay to decline invitations or leave situations that feel too risky. You should never have to feel bad or apologize for prioritizing your safety. Lead by example by sticking to what works for you and avoiding judgment.

Find some examples of the âCOVID Talkâ.

questionOriginal: Are children more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus? How can I help my children from getting sick?
questionText: Are children more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus? How can I help my children from getting sick?
answerOriginal:
No. Based on available evidence, children do not appear to be at higher risk for COVID-19 than adults. While some children and infants have been sick with COVID-19, adults make up most of the known cases to date. You can encourage your child to help stop the spread of COVID-19 by teaching them to do the same things everyone should do to stay healthy.

  • Socialize with household members or one other trusted household that is also taking health and safety precautions.

  • Wash hands often using soap and water or hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

  • Avoid people who are sick (coughing and sneezing).

  • Clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces daily in household common areas (like tables, hard-backed chairs, doorknobs, light switches, remotes, handles, desks, toilets, sinks).

  • Wash items including washable plush toys, according to the manufacturerâs instructions. If possible, wash items using the warmest appropriate water setting for the items and dry items completely. Dirty laundry from a person who is sick can be washed with other peopleâs items.

As of May 6, Vermonters are now allowed to gather in small groups of 10 or fewer people as long as health and safety precautions are followed. Members of one household may now choose to socialize â and allow children to play â with members of another trusted household that is also taking health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

Find more resources for families with children and information from the CDC on caring for young children.
answerText:
No. Based on available evidence, children do not appear to be at higher risk for COVID-19 than adults. While some children and infants have been sick with COVID-19, adults make up most of the known cases to date. However, a few children have developed multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-C). Currently, information about MIS-C is limited, and the CDC is working to learn more.
You can teach your children to do the same things everyone can do to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask when youâre outside and canât keep 6 feet apart or anytime youâre inside with people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.
Socializing for children is important for their development and wellbeing. There are ways children can socialize but still stay safe and keep from getting and spreading COVID-19.
Find more resources for families with children and information from the CDC for children, teens and young adults.
You can find information about cases across age groups along with other COVID-19 data on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. More detailed information is in the weekly summaries of Vermont COVID-19 data, which include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
questionText: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
On April 27, a dental health care referral network for emergency dental procedures was set up. Read the April 27 Health Alert.

On April 10, Governor Phil Scott extended his order of dental health care professionals practicing in Vermont to suspend all elective dental care until May 15, 2020. This order applies to both children and adult patients. Read Addendum 9 to the Executive Order for more information.

Health care professionals must continue to be available to their patients as needed for emergencies and urgent care.

Read the March 23 Health Alert as it pertains to emergency and elective dental care in light of COVID-19, the rationale for this action, including definitions of what constitutes a dental emergency and conditions requiring urgent care.

Find more information for health care professionals.
answerText:
The challenge with dentistry is the generation of aerosols as part of many office-based activities. This includes dental hygiene through a variety of preventive, restorative, endodontic, periodontic and orthodontic procedures.
Dental health care professionals can resume all procedures, including those that generate aerosol. Read the Interim Guidance for Resuming Dental Services in Vermont.
Dentists and other health care providers must continue to be available to their patients as needed for emergencies and urgent care.
Find more information for health care professionals.

questionOriginal: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
questionText: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
answerOriginal:
• Isolation is for people who are sick with COVID-19.

  • Quarantine is for people with no symptoms and who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19 or are returning to Vermont from out of state for anything other than an essential purpose.

  • Self-observation is for other Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19.

For more information, see the What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation? chart.
answerText:
Isolation is when people with COVID-19 stay home, and away from other people, until they have recovered, to prevent further spread. Learn about the timeline for people with COVID-19 (with symptoms and without symptoms) from being exposed to being released from isolation.
If you test positive for COVID-19, the Health Department's team of expert contact tracers will call you to provide guidance and information on staying home. They will also ask you about your close contacts. Contact tracers call your close contacts to make sure they know to stay home and quarantine to prevent further spread. Learn more about the timeline for close contacts, from when they have may have been exposed, to when they can end quarantine.
Learn more about isolation, quarantine and self-observation and what to do if you have COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
questionText: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested.

Follow these guidelines to help keep others from getting sick:

Isolate at home:

  • Donât leave home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting a health care provider or emergency department. Wear a cloth face mask or covering if you need to leave home for medical care

  • Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.

  • Stay in a specific room in your home and use a separate bathroom, as much as possible. Stay at least 6 feet away from others in your home at all times and wear a cloth face mask or covering if you are in the same room with them. Donât share household items.

  • Have someone else care for your pets. There have been a small number of pets, including cats and dogs, reported to be infected with the COVID-19 virus, mostly after close contact with people with COVID-19. If you must care for your pet, wear a cloth face mask or covering, and wash your hands before and after.

Daily cleaning and washing:

  • Clean and disinfect surfaces in your separate room and bathroom. Have someone else clean the other areas of your home.

  • Thoroughly wash household items, like utensils, after using.

  • Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water arenât available.

Find out what to do if you are diagnosed with COVID-19.

For more information, see CDC's guidance on what to do if you are sick.
answerText:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
If you or a family member are sick, follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and your community:

Stay home except to get medical care.
Separate yourself from other people.
Monitor your symptoms.
Call ahead before visiting your doctor.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering when youâre around people and pets.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with your sleeve or a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Wash your hands often. Use an alcohol-based sanitizer if soap and water aren't available.
Avoid sharing personal household items.
Clean all high-touch surfaces in your home daily.

Find more details on what to do if you are sick from the CDC.
Find out what to do if you are diagnosed with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: How many people have recovered from COVID-19 in Vermont?
questionText: How many people have recovered from COVID-19 in Vermont?
answerOriginal: The number of Vermonters who have recovered from COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. There is also information on this page for how the number of people recovered is reported.
answerText:
The total number of people who have recovered from COVID-19 is updated daily on the Vermont Dashboard. You can find information on how the data for total people recovered are reported in the notes section of the dashboard. There are also more frequently asked questions about the data above the dashboard.
Weekly Data Summaries include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: If I go on vacation, do I need to quarantine before I return to work?
questionText: If I go on vacation, do I need to quarantine before I return to work?
answerOriginal:
If you travel to an approved county with a low rate of active infections, you do not need to quarantine.

If you travel to a county that is not approved, then you need to quarantine for 14 days, either before you come back to Vermont or upon your return to Vermont. This applies to both employees living in Vermont and employees who live in a neighboring state and commute to Vermont for work.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested with a PCR test. Find out how under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Your employer may provide sick or vacation time for you to complete your quarantine.
answerText:
If you travel toÂ certain counties with low rates of active casesÂ ("green"Â counties), you do not need to quarantine.
If you travel to a âredâ or âyellowâ county, then you need to quarantine for 14 days, either before you come back to Vermont or upon your return to Vermont. This applies to both employees living in Vermont and employees who live in a neighboring state and commute to Vermont for work.
If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
Your employer may provide sick or vacation time for you to complete your quarantine.
Find more information on returning to Vermont.

questionOriginal: How many people who have tested positive for COVID-19 are in my town or county?
questionText: How many people who have tested positive for COVID-19 are in my town or county?
answerOriginal:
You can find the number of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 by county on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. This map is updated daily.

There is also a map showing the number of Vermonters who have tested positive for COVID-19 by the town where they live. Residents of long-term care facilities and inmates at correctional facilities are included in the town of their facility when they were tested. This map is updated weekly.

The Health Department shares information for towns as a number range. This is to protect the privacy of people who have tested positive for COVID-19. If some information is made public (for example, gender, age, race, health condition, travel history), then a person could be identified, especially if the population of a town is small. This follows both federal and Vermont laws.

The COVID-19 virus is spreading throughout Vermont, and many people may have it and can spread it for up to two days before they show symptoms. It is safe to assume that the virus is in your town or community, and you should take steps to protect yourself and others.

A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.
answerText:
The number of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 by county is updated daily on the Vermont Dashboard.
The number of Vermonters who have tested positive for COVID-19 by the town where they live is updated weekly on the map of cases by town.
When looking at the county or town numbers, please remember that low or no recent cases is not the same as âsafer.â We know the virus is in our communities, and we should continue to follow health guidance to slow the spread of COVID-19 â no matter where we live in or visit. The maps reflect the number of people who had a positive test. There may be people in your county or town that have COVID-19 but have not been tested.
Weekly Data Summaries include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What is the percent of tests positive for COVID-19 in Vermont?
questionText: What is the percent of tests positive for COVID-19 in Vermont?
answerOriginal: You can find the percent of positive tests, or positivity rate, in Vermont on the Vermont Dashboard.
answerText: You can find the percent of positive tests, or positivity rate, in Vermont on the Vermont Dashboard.

questionOriginal: Are there any travel restrictions into Vermont? Are out-of-state visitors allowed?
questionText: Are there any travel restrictions into Vermont? Are out-of-state visitors allowed?
answerOriginal:
Visitors from other states, and countries, are still being asked not to come to Vermont. If they do, they are required to quarantine at home for 14 days after arriving in Vermont and before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or going for walks.

Anyone who leaves Vermont for more than one day for travel that is not âessential" is required to quarantine at home for 14 days after arriving in Vermont and before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or going for walks.

Essential travel is defined as travel required for personal safety; food, beverage or medicine; medical care; care of others; and to perform work, services or functions deemed critical to public health and safety, as well as economic and national security. Read Addendum 6 for more details.

For those who are in a 14-day quarantine, you may need to rely on neighbors, friends or family living outside of the household to deliver groceries to your home. Check your local grocery store to see if there is an option for home delivery or look for online sources for home delivery. Groceries should always be left at your door. Wash your hands before and after if a signature for receipt is required.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.

Read Addendum 7 and Addendum 13 for more information about travel into Vermont.
answerText:
If you are visiting or returning to Vermont you must quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. Staying in and completing quarantine is extremely important to help keep people from spreading the virus when they may not know they have it. We strongly encourage you to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
You can either:

Quarantine in your home state for 14 days before coming to Vermont if you are driving in your personal vehicle (including a rental vehicle or private plane) OR
Quarantine at a Vermont lodging facility or home for 14 days if you are traveling by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.

If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result. You must remain in quarantine until you travel to Vermont.
Limit your stops when traveling to Vermont, and only stop when necessary (for example, for fuel, food or rest).
When you stop, follow the general prevention steps: stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with, wear a face mask, avoid crowded indoor spaces, and wash your hands often. Stay home and do not travel if you are sick.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

questionOriginal: Are campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts open?
questionText: Are campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts open?
answerOriginal:
Campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts are only open for limited in-person operations.

Find up-to-date guidance for campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD).

Businesses must follow mandatory health and safety requirements from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) that requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.

Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses.
answerText:
Lodging facilities â hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts, inns, short-term rentals (for example, VRBO, Homeaway, Airbnb, etc.), and all public and private camping facilities, RV parks, seasonal resorts and marinas â may accept overnight reservations from Vermont residents and those who have met the quarantine requirement. Find details and up-to-date information on lodging, campgrounds and other accommodations from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD).
All guests must complete a health questionnaire upon check-in and must provide a Vermont driverâs license or sign a Certificate of Compliance certifying that they met the quarantine requirement or have traveled from a "green" county. Out-of-state guests are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert â a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for symptoms of COVID-19 â for daily reminders from the Vermont Department of Health.
Find more travel and quarantine information from the Health Department and answers to frequently asked questions about travel from the ACCD.
If you have a concern about lodging facilities that are violating the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order, fill out the Department of Public Safety's online non-compliance complaint form.

questionOriginal: Is it okay to travel within the United States? Do I need to quarantine when I return?
questionText: Is it okay to travel within the United States? Do I need to quarantine when I return?
answerOriginal:
Cases of COVID-19 have been reported in all states, and some areas are experiencing community spread of the disease. Travel increases your chances of getting and spreading COVID-19.

The CDC recommends you stay home as much as possible, especially if your trip is not essential, and practice social distancing especially if you are at higher risk of severe illness. Donât travel if you are sick or travel with someone who is sick.

In Vermont, people from other states and countries are still being asked not to visit. If they do, they are required to self-quarantine for at least 14 days after arriving in Vermont before engaging in any activities, such as grocery shopping or going for walks.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.
answerText:
COVID-19 cases and deaths have been reported in all 50 states and are rising. Travel increases your chances of getting and spreading COVID-19.
Staying home is the best way to protect yourself and others from getting sick. Donât travel if you are sick or if you have been around someone with COVID-19. Donât travel with someone who is sick. Read about travel during the COVID-19 pandemic if you are thinking of traveling away from your local community.
If you travel out of Vermont whether for a day trip or longer, you must quarantine in Vermont for 14 days when you return. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
If you are visiting outside Vermont for a longer period, and you will travel back to Vermont in a personal vehicle (including a rental vehicle or private plane), you may complete either a 14-day quarantine or if you have not had any symptoms of COVID-19, a 7-day quarantine followed by a negative PCR test in the state where you are visiting. Continue to quarantine from when you receive your test result until you travel to Vermont. You may then enter Vermont without further quarantine restrictions.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do when you return to Vermont.

questionOriginal: I have a second home or a seasonal home in Vermont. Can I come to Vermont?
questionText: I have a second home or a seasonal home in Vermont. Can I come to Vermont?
answerOriginal:
If you are a second or seasonal homeowner (including an RV located in Vermont), you are encouraged to stay in your primary home unless you donât have other options. However, the Governorâs Stay Home, Stay Safe Order does not prevent people from going to their seasonal home or RV.

Any individual returning to, or traveling to, Vermont from another state or country for non-essential reasons is required to quarantine at home for 14 days upon their return and before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or going for walks, and must comply with all of the Governorâs Stay Home, Stay Safe Order.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.
answerText:
If you are returning to your second or seasonal home in Vermont, you are required to quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. Staying in and completing quarantine is extremely important to help keep people from spreading the virus when they may not know they have it. We strongly encourage you to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
You can either:

Quarantine in your home state for 14 days before coming to Vermont if you are driving in your personal vehicle (including a rental vehicle or private plane) OR
Quarantine at a Vermont lodging facility or home for 14 days if you are traveling by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.

If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result. You must remain in quarantine until you travel to Vermont.
Limit your stops when traveling to Vermont, and only stop when absolutely necessary (for example, for fuel, food or rest).
When you stop, follow the general prevention steps: stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with, wear a face mask, avoid crowded indoor spaces, and wash your hands often. Stay home and do not travel if you are sick.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

questionOriginal: Are mass gatherings (ceremonies, events, fairs or festivals) allowed?
questionText: Are mass gatherings (ceremonies, events, fairs or festivals) allowed?
answerOriginal:
Vermonters are allowed to gather in groups of 25 or fewer people as long as health and safety precautions are followed. Choose other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

Vermonters may hold yard sales and garage sales with 25 or fewer people. Hosts and visitors must keep a distance of at least 6 feet from others, and it is recommended that they wear cloth face masks or coverings.

Gatherings of more than 25 people are still prohibited. This includes weddings, graduation ceremonies, and other social gatherings.

All traditional fairs and festivals have been canceled until further notice.

Organized outdoor markets, like flea markets, must follow the farmers market guidance from the Agency of Agriculture, Food & Markets (AAFM).

Farmers markets and pick-your-own farms and orchards must follow best practices outlined by AAFM.

Starting June 26, event venues, arts, culture and entertainment venues, and restaurants can hold events, such as weddings, funerals and parties, with certain occupancy limits and health and safety precautions. Outdoor services, events, and gatherings are strongly preferred.

Find more information on the health and safety requirements for sectors that are open from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

At any gathering or event, everyone should follow these general precautions:Â wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep aÂ 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.
answerText:
As Vermont sees a significant surge of new COVID-19 cases across the state, Vermonters are prohibited from gathering with people from other households beginning November 14, 2020. This includes both inside and outside social gatherings, and in public and private spaces. People who live alone may gather with members of their immediate family living in a different household. Read Governor ScottâsÂ Executive Order.
Information on large events, such as weddings, funerals, parties, concerts and sporting events is available from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development. Learn more about wedding ceremonies.
Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of getting or spreading COVID-19.
All traditional fairs and festivals have been canceled until further notice.
Organized outdoor markets, like flea markets, must follow the farmers market guidance from the Agency of Agriculture, Food & Markets (AAFM).
Farmers markets and pick-your-own farms and orchards must follow best practices outlined by AAFM.
Libraries, galleries, museums, theaters and other indoor arts, culture and entertainment organizations are open with certain occupancy limits and health and safety precautions.
Find more information on the health and safety requirements for sectors that are open from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What does close contact mean?
questionText: What does close contact mean?
answerOriginal:
Close contact means being within 6 feet, for a long time, of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 during their infectious period, which starts two days (48 hours) before any symptoms began and continues until they are recovered. Close contact does not mean being more than 6 feet away in the same indoor environment for a long period of time, walking by, or briefly being in the same room with someone.

A âlong period of timeâ is hard to define because it depends on whether the person was sick at the time and what type of interaction you had with that person. These examples can help you determine whether you were a close contact or not.

Examples of close contacts:

  • You live in the same home.

  • You are intimate partners.

  • You rode in the same car while the person was infectious.

  • You had dinner together while the person was infectious.

Examples of not close contacts:

  • You were their cashier at the grocery store.

  • You are a pharmacist who gave the person medication.

  • You were in front of the person in line at the store.

  • You are a coworker who briefly walked by to ask a question.

A team at the Health Department works with people with COVID-19 to identify their close contacts. This is called contact tracing. The team assesses each close contact for their exposure risk and gives them health guidance and recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions.

As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

The chart describing what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation has details about what you should do and not do, depending on your exposure risk.

Find out more about what to do if you are a close contact of someone who is diagnosed with COVID-19.
answerText:
Close contact means being within 6 feet, for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period, of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 during their infectious period. The infectious period starts two days before any symptoms began â or for people with COVID-19 who don't have symptoms, two days before they got tested â and continues until they are recovered.
Close contact does not mean being more than 6 feet away in the same indoor environment for a short period of time, walking by, or briefly being in the same room with someone.
Here are some examples:
Examples of close contacts:

You live in the same home.
You are intimate partners.
You rode in the same car while the person was infectious.
You had dinner together while the person was infectious.

Examples of not close contacts:

You were their cashier at the grocery store.
You were their server at a restaurant.
You are a pharmacist who gave the person medication.
You were in front of the person in line at the store.
You are a coworker who briefly walked by to ask a question.

If you are identified as a close contact,Â you will be contacted. The notification could come from the Health Department, your employer, school, or health care provider, for example.Â TheyÂ will call you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home. Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.
Consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Do I need to quarantine if someone I live with is waiting for their COVID-19 test results?
questionText: Do I need to quarantine if someone I live with is waiting for their COVID-19 test results?
answerOriginal:
You do not need to quarantine if you live with someone who is waiting for their test results only if you:

  • do not have symptoms of COVID-19.
  • have not had contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.
  • have not traveled out of Vermont for the past 14 days.

This means that you can go to school, work, or the grocery store.

Be sure to stay at least 6 feet from the person who is under quarantine. People who are under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.

If you have symptoms of COVID-19, talk with your health care provider. If you don't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearestÂ federally qualified health centerÂ or one ofÂ Vermont's free & referral clinics.

questionOriginal: Can we still have our wedding ceremony?
questionText: Can we still have our wedding ceremony?
answerOriginal:
At this time, marriage ceremonies are discouraged, and officiants must ask to postpone services. But if a ceremony is held, it must be in accordance with the governorâs orders. This includes limiting gatherings to fewer than 10 people in the same space at the same time.

Visitors from other states and countries are asked not to come to Vermont at this time. If they do come to Vermont, they must stay at home (quarantine) 14 days before participating in any activities out of their home or lodging.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.

However, there are some exceptions, and this guidance may change. Find up-to-date information on marriage ceremonies from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.
answerText:
As Vermont sees a significant surge of new COVID-19 cases across the state, Governor ScottâsÂ Executive Order prohibits gathering with people from other households as of November 14, 2020.Â This includes social gatherings that are inside and outside, in public and private spaces, as well as any gatherings that are incidental to ceremonies, holiday gatherings, parties and celebrations. People who live alone may gather with members of their immediate family living in a different household.
Find up-to-date information on wedding ceremonies, including the number of people that are allowed, from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.
If you or your guests are visiting Vermont, you must quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
If you have not hadÂ symptoms of COVID-19, you have theÂ optionÂ to get a PCR test on day 7Â and end your quarantine with a negative test result. You must remain in quarantine until you travel to Vermont.
There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.
Whenever possible, keep ceremonies outdoors. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Are bars and restaurants open?
questionText: Are bars and restaurants open?
answerOriginal:
On April 10, the Governor extended his order (effective Tuesday, March 17 at 2 p.m.) closing all bars and restaurants statewide until May 15.

Establishments can continue to offer food take out and delivery.

Find up-to-date guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements for bars, restaurants and food service from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD), which requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.

Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.
answerText:
Restaurants are open under certain health and safety requirements. Restaurants must close in-person dining at 10 p.m., but may provide curbside and delivery service after 10 p.m. For in-person dining, restaurants must seat only one household per table.
Bars and social clubs are closed for in-person service until further notice. Curbside and delivery service is allowed.
Find more details and up-to-date information about restaurants, catering, food service and bars from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

questionOriginal: What are the long-term health effects of COVID-19?
questionText: What are the long-term health effects of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
The CDC is working to learn more about the whole range of short- and long-term health effects associated with COVID-19. Many organs besides the lungs are affected by COVID-19, and there are many ways the infection can affect someoneâs health.

One of the health effects that the CDC is closely watching and working to understand relates to COVID-19 and the heart. Heart conditions associated with COVID-19 include inflammation and damage to the heart muscle itself, known as myocarditis, or inflammation of the covering of the heart, known as pericarditis. These conditions can occur by themselves or in combination. Heart damage may be an important part of severe disease and death from COVID-19, especially in older people with underlying illnesses. Heart damage like this might also explain some frequently reported long-term symptoms like shortness of breath, chest pain, and heart palpitations.

The risk of heart damage may not be limited to older and middle-aged adults. For example, young adults with COVID-19, including athletes, can also suffer from myocarditis. Severe heart damage has occurred in young, healthy people, but is rare. There may be more cases of mild effects of COVID-19 on the heart that can be diagnosed with special imaging tests, including in younger people with mild or minimal symptoms; however, the long-term significance of these mild effects on the heart are unknown. The CDC will continue to assess and provide updates as new data emerge.
answerText:
The CDC is working to learn more about the whole range of short- and long-term health effects associated with COVID-19. Many organs besides the lungs are affected by COVID-19, and there are many ways the infection can affect someoneâs health.
While most people with COVID-19 recover and return to normal health, some can have symptoms that can last for weeks or even months after their recovery. Even people who are not hospitalized and who have a mild illness can experience persistent or late symptoms. Studies are being done to learn more.
Find out what the long-term health symptoms and complications of COVID-19 are from the CDC.

questionOriginal: What if there is a case of COVID-19 in school?
questionText: What if there is a case of COVID-19 in school?
answerOriginal:
The Health Department quickly responds every time we receive a positive test result for COVID-19. A contact tracer calls the person who tested positive (or their parent) within 24 hours, asks them questions about their recent activities and who theyâve been in contact with during their infectious period, and gives instructions on staying home. The team contacts the school if the person was there while infectious. Schools do not need to take action if someone with COVID-19 was not at the school during their infectious period.

The Health Department will:

  • Work closely with the school and ask about who had close contact (within 6 feet for at least 15 minutes) with the person with COVID-19 while they were infectious, like classmates and teachers. Information that identifies the individual will only be shared if consent was given.
  • Reach out to all people with close contact and give them information about quarantine and testing.
  • Discuss next steps with school administration, including whether to temporarily move to remote instruction.

The school will:

  • Close off any areas where the person spent longer than 15 minutes (like a classroom, gym, or a cafeteria) then clean and disinfect the areas.
  • Communicate with parents and staff about the situation, and encourage everyone to answer calls from the Health Department for contact tracing, if they get called. Contact tracers only call the people who our infectious disease experts determine have had close contact with a person with COVID-19 while they were infectious.
  • Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces in the school.
  • Make sure that anyone who tests positive for COVID-19 stays home from school (isolation) until they can return.
  • Make sure that anyone who had close contact with someone with COVID-19 while they were infectious stays home from school (quarantine) until they can return. Someone under quarantine does not have COVID-19 and cannot pass it to others, but they may become infected within 14 days.

Learn more about the Health Department's response to COVID-19 cases.

Several resources for school administrators, nurses and COVID coordinators are available on the Health Department School web page including a quick reference guide for when someone with COVID-19 was at school while infectious.

You can learn more about that and other information about what parents can expect for pre-K through 12th grade as schools reopen for the fall.
answerText:
The Health Department quickly responds every time we receive a positive test result for COVID-19. Schools are encouraged to call the Health Department when learning of a positive test result.
The Health Department will:

Contact the person who tested positive (or their parent/guardian), ask them questions about their recent activities and who theyâve been in close contact with, and give instructions on staying home.
Notify the school if the person who tested positive is associated with a school.
Schools do not need to take action if the Health Department determines that there is no risk of further spread at the school. For example, if the person with COVID-19 was not at school during their infectious period, there would not have been an opportunity to spread the virus to others at school.
Work closely with the school to identify close contacts at school (within 6 feet for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period) of the person who tested positive with COVID-19 during their infectious period.
Discuss next steps with school administration, including whether to temporarily close the classroom for in-person instruction. These decisions are made on a case by case basis. The Health Department will provide guidance based on a number of factors, including the level of community transmission, the number of students or staff infected, the status of contact tracing, the number of days the infectious person was at school, infection control policies and practices, the number and structure of classes, pods, or grades affected, and other opportunities for transmission, like extra-curricular activities.

The school will:

Close off any areas where the person spent longer than 15 minutes (like a classroom, gym, or a cafeteria) then clean and disinfect the areas.
Communicate with parents and staff about the situation.
Support the Health Departmentâs efforts by notifying people associated with the school who have been identified as close contacts. The school will provide them with Health Department guidance and information on quarantine and testing. Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for up to 14 days.
Make sure that anyone who tests positive for COVID-19 stays home from school (isolation) until they can return. Find out what to do if you test positive for COVID-19.
Make sure that anyone who had close contact with someone with COVID-19 while they were infectious stays home from school (quarantine) until they can return. Find out what to do if you are a close contact.

For more information:

Learn more about theÂ Health Department's response to COVID-19 cases.
Find a table showing the number of COVID-19 cases in Vermont K-12 schools while infectious, by school name.
Several resources for school administrators, nurses and COVID-19 coordinators are available on the Health Department'sÂ PreK-12 Schools web pageÂ including a quick reference guide for whenÂ someone with COVID-19 was at school while infectious.
Learn about when your child can return to school after being sick.

questionOriginal: What is an outbreak of COVID-19?
questionText: What is an outbreak of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Outbreaks have different definitions depending on the setting in which they occur, including community, educational, congregate living or workplace settings. They can be two or more cases that are epidemiologically connected.

Learn more about what an outbreak means, when they are considered resolved, how many have happened in each type of setting, plus find more data on outbreaks that have happened in Vermont in our Weekly Data Summary.
answerText:
The Health Department refers to âsituationsâ when one person who tested positive for COVID-19 was at a setting (for example, at school, their work place, or a health care facility) or an event (for example, a private party) while they were infectious and there is a concern that the virus could spread to others who attended the event or who were present at the setting. Situations usually require more follow up than only notifying close contacts. The Health Department monitors situations but does not report any data on them.
However, a situation may become an outbreak. An outbreak means that the virus has spread to more than one person associated with the setting or the event. Learn more about what an outbreak means, when they are considered resolved, how many have happened in each type of setting, plus find more data on outbreaks that have happened in Vermont in our Weekly Data Summary.

questionOriginal: I am in isolation because I tested positive for COVID-19, but I can't avoid close contact with someone I take care of. Do they need to quarantine?
questionText: I am in isolation because I tested positive for COVID-19, but I can't avoid close contact with someone I take care of. Do they need to quarantine?
answerOriginal: Yes. In situations where you have COVID-19 (for example, youâre a parent) and you cannot avoid close contact with those you take care of (for example, your children), then the people you take care of should stay home and away from other people while you are sick. They should also quarantine for 14 days after you are able to end home isolation. Learn more about living with someone who has COVID-19 and cannot avoid close contact (Scenario 4).

In situations where you have COVID-19 (for example, youâre a parent) and you cannot avoid close contact with those you take care of (for example, your children), then the people you take care of should stay home and away from other people while you are sick. They should also quarantine for 14 days after you are able to end home isolation. Learn more about living with someone who has COVID-19 and cannot avoid close contact (Scenario 4).

questionOriginal: I take care of someone who is in quarantine, but I canât avoid close contact with them. Do I need to quarantine?
questionText: I take care of someone who is in quarantine, but I canât avoid close contact with them. Do I need to quarantine?
answerOriginal:
In situations where close contact cannot be avoided, close contacts of the person under quarantine do not also need to quarantine. For example, if someone under quarantine depends on another person for care and basic needs, and close contact cannot be avoided, the caregiver may continue with activities outside of the home. For example, the caregiver may continue to go to work, school, child care, the grocery store, etc.

As much as possible, continue to practice these prevention steps. Stay at least 6 feet from the person who is under quarantine. People who are under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.

Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from others to prevent further spread. Quarantine means staying at a home or dwelling for 14 days since the day they were potentially exposed, before doing any activities outside of the home. People in quarantine should separate themselves from others and check themselves for symptoms.

questionOriginal: What should businesses and non-profits do?
questionText: What should businesses and non-profits do?
answerOriginal:
Vermont is starting a phased approach to reopen the economy, balancing overall social and economic wellbeing with preventing a rise in COVID-19 that would set us back.

Find up-to-date, sector-specific guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD). This includes requiring employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others and other protective measures.

Businesses deemed âessentialâ may continue to operate under pre-existing guidance, with the addition of the mandatory health and safety requirements. Find more on new work safe additions to the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order.

Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.
answerText:

The Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) has the resources businesses need on the COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:

A step-by-step reopening guide for businesses
Up-to-date phased restart guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face masks or coverings. Businesses and non-profits may require customers or clients to wear masks.
Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses

Find more health resources for businesses from the Health Department.
The Health Department and Agency of Agriculture do not recommend the use of fogging, fumigation, âelectrostatic or wide-area spraying on hard surfaces to control the spread of COVID-19. These methods, while they can be effective,Â âare unnecessary, do not clean contaminated surfaces. They also may result in chemical exposures to workers and the public. Additionally, the Environmental Protection Agency does not recommend using these methods to apply disinfectants unless the label specifically states it is appropriate to do so.

questionOriginal: What is quarantine?
questionText: What is quarantine?
answerOriginal:
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from others. It is for people with no symptoms who are returning to Vermont from certain out-of-state locations or people who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19. Quarantine helps prevent the spread of COVID-19 before a person knows they are sick, or if they are infected with the virus and donât have symptoms. Learn more about the timeline for close contacts, from when they have may have been exposed to when they can end quarantine.

Quarantine means staying at a home or dwelling for 14 days since the day they were potentially exposed to COVID-19 before doing any activities outside of the home, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. People in quarantine should separate themselves from others and check themselves for symptoms.

We strongly encourage anyone in quarantine to sign up forÂ daily symptom check reminders.

Check the latest quarantine guidance for people visiting or returning to Vermont and find answers to travel-related quarantine questions.

This means you canât do any activities outside of your home, like going to school, work, or out to do errands or recreation. You should separate yourself from others and check for symptoms.

people who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19 (day 1 of your quarantine starts the day after you were last in contact with them)

people with no symptoms who are visiting Vermont (day 1 of your quarantine starts the day after you arrive in Vermont)
people who have gathered with another household (day 1 of your quarantine starts the day after the gathering)
