questionOriginal: Why are social gatherings prohibited right now?
questionText: Why are social gatherings prohibited right now?
answerOriginal:
Vermont is seeing a surge in new COVID-19 cases. Recent data have shown that social gatherings, both inside and outside, at homes, bars and social clubs, and among sports teams is currently driving outbreaks in Vermont.

Because of this, Governor Scott has temporarily prohibited social gatherings with people from other households. People who live alone may get together with members of their immediate family living in a different household.

We must all do our part to slow the spread, ensure hospitals are not overwhelmed, help schools continue to offer in-person instruction, and keep as many Vermonters working as possible.

Vermont data at this time does not point to dining at restaurants, gyms, or other close contact business as drivers of outbreaks, and current safety protocols at these businesses are working.

We know this is difficult, but hope that as Vermonters follow this guidance, and we can return to the low case numbers we had and ease restrictions once again.
answerText:
Vermont is seeing a surge in new COVID-19 cases. Recent data have shown that social gatherings, both inside and outside, at homes, bars and social clubs, and among sports teams are currently driving outbreaks in Vermont. This is why there are restrictions on social gatherings at this time.
This is what you cannot do:

You are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. This includes all inside and outside social, recreational and entertainment gatherings, and in public and private spaces. For example, this means you cannot go over to a family member or friendâs house or go to a restaurant with someone you donât live with.
Visitors to Vermont cannot gather with Vermonters or with people from another traveling group. This includes sharing lodging with another household or traveling group. Travelers may not stay with a Vermont host or stay in a Vermont lodging establishment or short-term rental with another household. Even if they have completed a quarantine, or intend to quarantine with another household, they may not gather with another household in Vermont.

This is what you can do:

People who live alone may gather with people who live in one other household.
People can take in and shelter those from another household who are living in a dangerous, unhealthy or otherwise unsafe situation.
You can do outdoor fitness activities with one other person from another household. However, both of you must stay at least 6 feet away from each other and wear a mask at all times. For example, you can bike, hike, walk or run with one of your neighbors.
Visitors to Vermont can socialize only with the people they are traveling with.

It is not considered a social gathering if you have contact with someone for less than 15 minutes, you both are wearing masks, and you stay at least 6 feet apart (for example, checking on a neighbor, friend or family member not in your household). You are allowed to come in contact with members of other households in settings that continue to operate â such as schools, workplaces, retail stores, close contact businesses, etc. â as long as all the required health protocols are followed.
Vermont data at this time does not point to dining at restaurants, gyms, or other close contact businesses as drivers of outbreaks, and current safety protocols at these businesses are working. This is why they are remaining open.
We must all do our part to slow the spread, ensure hospitals are not overwhelmed, help schools continue to offer in-person instruction, and keep as many Vermonters working as possible.
We know this is difficult, but hope that as Vermonters follow this guidance, and we can return to the low case numbers we had and ease restrictions once again.
Read Governor Scottâs Executive Order.

questionOriginal: Why are rates used on the town map, and how are they calculated?
questionText: Why are rates used on the town map, and how are they calculated?
answerOriginal:
The rate of recent cases by town map reflects the rate of cases of COVID-19 among Vermont residents per 10,000 people, by town of residence, from the past two weeks. Rates are commonly used because they allow us to compare the number of cases across towns that have different population sizes.

To calculate the rate by town in the last two weeks, we take the number of cases reported in the last two weeks in a town and divide it by that townâs population. That number is multiplied by 10,000 people. This is the rate, or number of cases per 10,000 people.

Use the map to compare how prevalent COVID-19 is in a town over the past two weeks, relative to other towns. The map may help communities assess how their town is doing and take additional actions to prevent the spread of COVID-19 when necessary.

When looking at the town rates, please remember that having a lower rate of recent cases is not the same as âsafer.â We know the virus is in our communities, and we should continue to follow health guidance to slow the spread of COVID-19 â no matter where we live or where we visit. The data reflect the rate of people who had a positive test. There may be people in your town that have COVID-19 but have not been tested.

questionOriginal: I had COVID-19, received a positive antibody test, or got a COVID-19 vaccine. Does that mean I am exempt from the travel quarantine or social gathering requirements?
questionText: I had COVID-19, received a positive antibody test, or got a COVID-19 vaccine. Does that mean I am exempt from the travel quarantine or social gathering requirements?
answerOriginal:
The Governorâs executive orders do not exempt people who had COVID-19, received a positive antibody test, or got the COVID-19 vaccine. This means that even if you had COVID-19, received a positive antibody test, or got a COVID-19 vaccine, you must quarantine when you travel or return to Vermont under the current travel guidelines. This also means that you are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with under the current social gathering guidelines.

It is not yet known if people who recover from COVID-19 can get infected again. There are no confirmed reports to date of a person being reinfected with COVID-19 within three months of initial infection.

Additionally, if you have received a positive antibody test, that does not mean you have âproof of immunityâ from COVID-19.

It is also not yet known if people who get a COVID-19 vaccine can still infect others with the virus. Find up-to-date information about the COVID-19 vaccine.

Currently, we recommend that everyone, including people who had COVID-19, received a positive antibody test, or got the COVID-19 vaccine continue to follow the prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

  • Stay home if you are sick.
  • Wash your hands often.
  • Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
  • Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
  • Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

questionOriginal: What information is available for long-term care facilities and other facilities that serve older Vermonters (group homes, nursing homes, assisted living, and state therapeutic care residences)?
questionText: What information is available for long-term care facilities and other facilities that serve older Vermonters (group homes, nursing homes, assisted living, and state therapeutic care residences)?
answerOriginal:
Starting June 19, facilities may offer limited visitation outside with residents. Check with the facility first before planning a visit.

Medically necessary personnel and visitors for residents receiving end-of-life care are allowed inside. Read the executive order.

The Health Department recommends that all health care personnel in long-term care facilities and other congregate settings where health care is provided wear face masks, regardless of the presence of COVID-19 in the facility.

Any new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine period first.

Senior Centers may reopen with guidance from the Health Department and the Department of Aging and Independent Living. Adult Day programs remain closed.

There is guidance Â­on preventing the spread of COVID-19 for managers and owners of senior living communities, which includes making a plan, preparing common spaces and communicating with residents/staff, in addition to outlining the role of the Health Department.

Find more guidance and information for long-term care and group living settings.

There is a table showing active outbreaks in long-term care facilities, which is updated on Tuesdays and Fridays.
The Health Department recommends surveillance testing at long-term care facilities to identify people with COVID-19 and to help stop outbreaks in long-term care facilities.

questionOriginal: Can I volunteer to help with the Stateâs response to COVID-19?
questionText: Can I volunteer to help with the Stateâs response to COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Yes, people with medical and health care skills and those with other needed skills can sign up for volunteer assistance to support the stateâs response to COVID-19. We currently have a contact tracing team in place, but these are other ways you can help.

People with medical or other health care backgrounds are needed to support the health care providers responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. Vermontâs Medical Reserve Corps units are community-based groups of volunteers who supplement local emergency and public health resources with their existing skills.

Sign up with the Vermont Medical Reserve Corps if you:

  • Are a licensed and certified health care professional

  • Have health, mental health, or other types of clinical or professional experience

  • Have health care administrative experience, such as with medical data entry or language translators

  • Have worked with displaced individuals, such as homeless shelter programs

Vermont has eased licensing requirements for the purposes of aiding this emergency response. Physicians, physician assistants and podiatrists can learn more on the Board of Medical Practice website. Other medical professionals, including nurses and osteopathic physicians, can learn more on the Office of Professional Regulation's website.

Other individuals who have needed skills (for example, drivers, food service, construction, IT, security, skilled trades, etc.), can sign up at vermont.gov/volunteer and indicate their expertise and availability.

Vermonters can also contribute to blood banks, food banks, and other emergency supply efforts. The American Red Cross of Northern New England faces a severe blood shortage and many local food banks and other community organizations are in need of support and donations of supplies.

Give blood: Learn how to safely donate blood with the American Red Cross.

Support your local Foodbank by donating online or you can text GIVEHEALTH to 85511. The Vermont Foodbank can help if you need it.

You can also help your neighbors â older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have underlying medical conditions should stay home as much as possible. Go shopping for a neighbor or someone else in need, keep an older neighbor company by phone or at a safe distance. When volunteering please follow the guidelines on being a good neighbor.
answerText:
Yes! We are in need of nurses and caregivers for both paid and volunteer positions. Additionally, we need people who can help keep our essential infrastructure operational. We need people from across different sectors and disciplines to assist. There are several ways to become involved. As our needs will change over time, be sure to check back often.
Find paid or volunteer opportunities.
Vermont has eased licensing requirements for the purpose of helping out with the COVID-19 response. Learn more about getting a temporary license if you are a health professional.
Here are other ways you can help:

Donate blood with the American Red Cross.
Support your local Foodbank by volunteering or donating online, or you can text GIVEHEALTH to 85511.
Donate or volunteer with community organizations or emergency supply efforts.
Help your neighbors â older adults and people of any age who have underlying medical conditions should stay close to home as much as possible. Go shopping for a neighbor or someone else in need, keep an older neighbor company by phone or at a safe distance.

When volunteering please follow the guidelines on being a good neighbor.

questionOriginal: How are the Governorâs executive orders being enforced?
questionText: How are the Governorâs executive orders being enforced?
answerOriginal:
Enforcement of the Governorâs executive orders â Be Smart, Stay Safe â is mainly done through education and voluntary compliance. Law enforcement officers are encouraged to talk to people or businesses if they see or are made aware of possible violations.

  • The orders do not close roads, do not establish roadblocks or checkpoints, and do not require people to show their identification.
  • People may be out and about. Motor vehicles with Vermont and out-of-state registrations are allowed to operate.
  • There will be no motor vehicle stops and no people detained for questioning about their travel.

If you have a concern about businesses, lodging establishments, short-term rental properties, nonprofits, other entitiesÂ that are violating the Governorâs orders or people who are not quarantining as required, call your local law enforcement agency or file a report online.

questionOriginal: Are sports and outdoor activities allowed?
questionText: Are sports and outdoor activities allowed?
answerOriginal:
We encourage Vermonters to go outside and enjoy the fresh air. Exercise, outdoor activities, and taking in Vermontâs natural beauty is important for our mind and bodies.

Businesses, non-profit and government entities that support or offer outdoor recreation and outdoor fitness activities with low or no direct physical contact can open on May 7. These include, but are not limited to, state and municipal parks, recreation associations, trail networks, golf courses, big game check stations and guided expeditions.

Campgrounds, marinas and beaches are not permitted to open at this time. Find up-to-date information on outdoor recreation and campgrounds from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.

Contact sports and games should not be played at this time.

We can safely continue to enjoy outdoor activities with these measures:

  • Stay close to home. Find local outdoor recreation areas and consider day trips that are close to home. Only drive with members of your household.

  • Take health and safety precautions. Keep the virus from spreading by staying at least 6 feet apart from other people outside of your household, washing or sanitizing your hands, and staying home when you are sick.

  • Bring a cloth face mask with you. Put a cloth face mask or covering on if you encounter other people and stop to chat or if you are on a crowded trail or bike path.

  • Be cautious and choose low-risk activities to avoid injury. This will help lower the burden on our hospitals and health care system.

  • Respect signs for closed areas, trails and land. Check Trail Finder to find out if your trail is currently open before you visit. Call ahead or check websites for information on outdoor recreation facilities before you head out.

  • Choose no-contact sports: For example, biking, hiking, horseback riding, tennis, boating and golfing. Outdoor basketball courts may be open to shoot hoops, but signage should be posted prohibiting contact games. Do not share sports equipment with people outside of your household.

  • Check for ticks and wear an EPA-registered tick repellent. When youâre out walking or spending time in your backyard, remember that ticks are active this time of year. Find out how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.

Find out more about outdoor recreation and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation and the Vermont Fish and Wildlife Department.

Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

These include, but are not limited to, state parks, municipal parks, recreation associations, pools, beaches, play structures or playgrounds, trail networks, golf courses, big game check stations and guided expeditions.

questionOriginal: What is contact tracing?
questionText: What is contact tracing?
answerOriginal:
Contact tracing is a strategy used to determine the source of an infection and how it is spreading. Finding people who are close contacts to a person who has tested positive for COVID-19, and therefore at higher risk of becoming infected themselves, can help prevent further spread of the virus.

A team of callers tries to reach anyone who has tested positive for COVID-19. They ask the patient questions about their activities within a certain timeframe â to help identify anyone they had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than six feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) Those contacts might include family members, co-workers or health care providers. Please note, the Health Department only uses a live person for contact tracing and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call.

The team then gets in touch with those contacts and provides health guidance on what to do if you are a close contact of someone who is diagnosed with COVID-19. A close contact is asked to stay home for 14 days and watch for symptoms.

While we have been successful in contact tracing, we will continue to add resources and personnel needed to address any increase in the number of people who test positive, which we expect to happen with more testing. This includes the use of technology to help in these efforts. We will be using an app called SARA Alert, a secure monitoring and reporting system for public health that is being used in other states. This system will allow us to offer people who have tested positive for COVID-19, and their close contacts, to enroll in a text-based system to help us keep in touch and monitor their symptoms.

As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.
answerText:
Contact tracing is used to provide education, support and guidance to people who are diagnosed with an infectious disease. Itâs also used to identify people who have been in close contact with them, so they can take steps to stop the disease from spreading to others.
If you test positive for COVID-19, you will get a call from the Health Department. A trained public health worker, called a contact tracer, will give you guidance to stay home and away from other people until you recover. This stops the virus from spreading to other people. They will ask you questions about your symptoms, activities, and who you may have come into contact with during a specific period of time. This information is only used to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
If you are identified as a close contact, you will be contacted. The notification will come from the Health Department or a place you went to recently (for example, your employer, your childâs school, or your health care provider might contact you). They will contact you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home.
If you receive a text message from 89361, this is a notification from the Health Department that you are a close contact of someone who tested positive for COVID-19. Soon you will receive a call from a Health Department Contact Tracer. Find out what you need to do if you are a close contact.
Itâs important to answer the call and to answer questions as completely as possible to make sure everyone knows what steps to take to prevent further spread of the virus. Governor Scottâs Executive Order calls on Vermonters to comply with all contact tracing requests.
All restaurants and other businesses are keeping a 30-day log of employee and guest names and contact information in case contact tracing is needed.
Consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.
Currently, Vermont is not participating in the contact tracing notifications that are available on some cell phones. We are waiting to see how successful this service is in other states who are participating. If itâs proven to be effective, we will consider using it.
Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.

questionOriginal: What is known about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) associated with COVID-19?
questionText: What is known about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) associated with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC, Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) is a condition where different body parts can become inflamed, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, brain, skin, eyes, or gastrointestinal organs. We do not yet know what causes MIS-C. However, we know that many children with MIS-C had the COVID-19 virus, or had been around someone with COVID-19. MIS-C can be serious, even deadly, but most children who were diagnosed with this condition have gotten better with medical care.

MIS-C is rare, and it remains unknown whether multisystem inflammatory syndrome only occurs in children or if it also can occur in adults.

Learn more about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Health.
answerText:
According to the CDC, Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) is a condition where different body parts can become inflamed, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, brain, skin, eyes, or gastrointestinal organs. We do not yet know what causes MIS-C. However, we know that many children with MIS-C had the COVID-19 virus, or had been around someone with COVID-19. Children with MIS-C may have a fever and various symptoms, including abdominal (gut) pain, vomiting, diarrhea, neck pain, rash, bloodshot eyes, or feeling extra tired. MIS-C can be serious, even deadly, but most children who were diagnosed with this condition have gotten better with medical care.
MIS-C is rare, and it remains unknown whether multisystem inflammatory syndrome only occurs in children or if it also can occur in adults.
Learn more about Multisystem Inflammatory Disease and COVID-19 from the Health Department.

questionOriginal: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
questionText: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you have been in close contact with a person who tested positive for COVID-19, monitor yourself for symptoms. This includes checking your temperature every day, watching for symptoms and staying home.

If you develop symptoms of COVID-19 and are a close contact of someone who tested positive, you should:

  1. Call your health care provider and

  2. Call the Vermont Department of Health at 802-863-7240.

If you do not develop symptoms, you do not need to call the Health Department.

Read what to do if you're a close contact of someone with COVID-19.
answerText:
When someone tests positive for COVID-19, the Health Department works with them to identify their close contacts. Generally, these are people you were within 6 feet of, for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period, during the time they were infectious (contagious).
If you are identified as a close contact, you will be contacted. The notification will come from the Health Department or a place you went to recently (for example, your employer, your childâs school, or your health care provider might contact you). They will contact you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home.
If you receive a textÂ message from 89361, this is a notification from the Health Department that you are a close contact of someone whoÂ tested positive for COVID-19. Soon you will receive a call from aÂ Health Department Contact Tracer.Â Find out what you need to do if you are a close contact.
If you are not identified as a close contact, then you will not be called. While contact tracers work to identify all close contacts, all might not be identified. If you think that you might be a close contact but didn't get a call, you may take precautions by quarantining for 14 days since the last day you were in contact with that person, and get tested on day 7 or after if you have not had any symptoms.
If you are not a close contact of a person who tested positive, you can continue to follow the prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.
Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.

questionOriginal: Can I come to Vermont to ski?
questionText: Can I come to Vermont to ski?
answerOriginal:
Vermont ski areas will open for the 2021-21 ski season under mandatory health and safety guidelines, which include limits on lift and lodge capacities. If you come to Vermont to ski, you must follow attest that you completed Vermontâs quarantine requirements.

That means you must quarantine for 14 days before coming to Vermont. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result. You must remain in quarantine until you travel to Vermont.

If you are coming fromÂ certain counties with low rates of active casesÂ (âgreenâ counties), you do not need to quarantine.

You will also be required to give your contact information to the ski resort in case contact tracing is needed.

You are required to wear a mask when you are in a lodge or anytime you canât stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with. Try to avoid crowded places as much as possible and stay at least 6 feet away from people you didnât travel with.

Be sure to check with the ski resort before you plan your trip to find out any other rules that the resort has.
answerText:
Vermont ski areas will open this season under mandatory health and safety guidelines, which include limits on lift and lodge capacities. If you come to Vermont to ski or snowboard, you must attest that you completed Vermontâs quarantine requirements.
That means you must quarantine for 14 days before coming to Vermont. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result. You must remain in quarantine until you travel to Vermont.
You will also be required to give your contact information to the ski resort in case contact tracing is needed.
You are required to wear a mask when you are in a lodge and anytime you are in a public space. Try to avoid crowded places as much as possible and stay at least 6 feet away from people you didnât travel with.
As of November 14, 2020, you are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. This includes all inside and outside social, recreational and entertainment gatherings, and in public and private spaces. This means that visitors to Vermont can only socialize with the people they are traveling with. They cannot gather with Vermonters or with people from another traveling group. Learn more about what this means.
Be sure to check with the ski resort before you plan your trip to find out any other rules that the resort has.
Find more travel and quarantine information.

questionOriginal: Are there any recommendations for older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions?
questionText: Are there any recommendations for older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC, some people might be at higher risk of getting very sick from COVID-19, including older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have serious underlying medical conditions like heart disease, diabetes, lung disease or moderate to severe asthma, severe obesity, chronic kidney disease undergoing dialysis, liver disease, or people who are immunocompromised including cancer treatment. People who live in a nursing home or long-term care facility are also at high risk of getting very sick from COVID-19.

In addition to the general COVID-19 prevention steps, older adults and people with underlying medical conditions should take extra precautions including:

  • Continue your medications and do not change your treatment plan without talking to your health care provider.

  • Stay home as much as possible, leaving only for essential purposes, like going to the grocery store and pharmacy. Consider having groceries or medications delivered.

  • Have at least a 2-week supply of prescription and non-prescription medications.

  • Talk to your health care provider about whether your vaccinations are up to date.

  • Do not delay getting emergency care for your underlying medical condition because of COVID-19.

  • Call your health care provider if you have any concerns about your underlying medical conditions or if you get sick and think that you may have COVID-19.

Read the CDCâs full guidance on people who are at higher risk for serious illness from COVID-19.
answerText:
According to the CDC, the risk for severe illness from COVID-19 increases with age, with older adults at highest risk, and is higher for people of any age with certain underlying medical conditions. Severe illness means that the person with COVID-19 may require hospitalization, intensive care, or a ventilator to help them breathe, or they may even die.
If you are in one of these groups, take these extra precautions in addition to the COVID-19 prevention steps:

Stay close to home as much as possible. Traveling out of state is not recommended since the virus is still widespread in neighboring states and across the country.
Be aware of your surroundings. Choose outdoor settings over indoor settings. Pay attention to the size of the space, crowding, the number of people there, and if they are wearing face coverings and keeping a 6-foot distance.
Choose activities that donât require close contact. Minimize close contact while talking or doing anything that requires exertion, shouting or singing.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with

The CDC recommends other populations also take extra precautions, like pregnant people, people experiencing homelessness, and people with disabilities.

questionOriginal: How do I wash or sanitize my hands to keep from getting sick?
questionText: How do I wash or sanitize my hands to keep from getting sick?
answerOriginal:
CDC recommends the following for hand hygiene: Household members should clean hands often, including immediately after removing gloves and after contact with someone who is ill, by washing hands with soap and water for 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available and hands are not visibly dirty, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. However, if hands are visibly dirty, always wash hands with soap and water.

Hand Sanitizer Recipe (based on recipe from the World Health Organization):

  • 1 cup (250 mL) isopropyl alcohol (91%)

  • 1 teaspoon (5 mL) glycerol (or other moisturizer such as aloe vera gel, warm honey or olive oil)

  • 2 Tablespoons (33 mL) water

Add the ingredients in the order listed above to a clean container, mixing with a spoon. If using honey, stir until the honey is completely dissolved. Keep this mixture out of the reach of children. The final concentration of isopropyl alcohol in this mixture is 75%, so keep it away from flames.
answerText:
The CDC recommends washing your hands often with soap and water for 20 seconds. To prevent the spread of germs during the COVID-19 pandemic, itâs especially important to wash your hands before and after:

Touching your eyes, nose or mouth
Eating or preparing food
Blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing
Touching your mask
Entering and leaving a public place
Touching an item or surface that may be frequently touched by other people (such as door handles, tables, gas pumps, shopping carts, or electronic cashier registers/screens, etc.)
Caring for someone who is sick

If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. Cover all surfaces of your hands and rub them together until they feel dry. Always wash your hands with soap and water if they look dirty.

questionOriginal: What is Sara Alert?
questionText: What is Sara Alert?
answerOriginal:
Sara Alert is a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19. People who have tested positive for COVID-19, their close contacts, and people traveling or returning to Vermont can quickly and easily sign up for to receive free daily reminders to check themselves for symptoms by email, text or phone call. If symptoms are reported, the Health Department will reach out to provide guidance and next steps. Sara Alert helps our public health teams contain the spread of COVID-19.

Please note, Sara Alert is not a contact tracing system. It is not GPS based, so it does not monitor your movements.

If you are traveling or returning to Vermont, you are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.

Sign up for Sara Alert.
answerText:
Sara Alert is a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19. Sara Alert is for:

People who test positive for COVID-19
Close contacts of people with COVID-19
People visiting or returning to Vermont

Once you sign up, Sara Alert sends daily reminders until they automatically stop after two weeks. You can choose to receive messages by email, text or phone. If you report symptoms, the Health Department will reach out to provide guidance and next steps.
Sara Alert is not a contact tracing system. It is not GPS-based, so it does not monitor your movements or track your location.
Here are some reasons why you should sign up for Sara Alert:

You get fast, easy, and free reminders to check yourself for symptoms.
You get quick access to the Health Department for guidance and information if you develop symptoms.
It helps our public health teams contain the spread of COVID-19.

If you are a close contact of someone who has COVID-19, you will be given the link to sign up for Sara Alert when you are notified.
If you are visiting Vermont or recently returned to Vermont, learn more about Sara Alert and sign up. Visitors or returning travelers who are currently enrolled in Sara Alert who have questions about their messages can email the Travel Team or call 802-863-7240 (option 6).

questionOriginal: How can I make my own homemade cloth face mask or covering?
questionText: How can I make my own homemade cloth face mask or covering?
answerOriginal:
Homemade cloth face masks or coverings can be made using simple materials found in most homes. For example, an old t-shirt or bandanna and rubber bands or hair ties. Your cloth face mask or covering should include multiple layers of fabric and allow you to be able to breathe easily. Watch a quick video by the CDC on how to make your own cloth face mask.

As the state continues to reopen, it is more important than ever to make wearing cloth face masks or coverings a habit and to bring one with you whenever you leave home. Cloth face masks or coverings need to be worn in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, visiting a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19.
answerText:
Homemade cloth face masks or coverings can be made using simple materials found in most homes, for example, an old t-shirt or bandanna and rubber bands or hair ties. Your cloth face mask or covering should include multiple layers of fabric and allow you to be able to breathe easily. Watch a quick video by the CDC on how to make your own cloth face mask.
You are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces (for example, businesses, public buildings, parks), group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes), and other places where itâs not possible to stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
In private settings (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you wear a face mask or covering anytime you're around people you donât live with.

questionOriginal: What is the difference between COVID-19 and the flu?
questionText: What is the difference between COVID-19 and the flu?
answerOriginal:
COVID-19 is a new disease and we are still learning about how it makes people sick.

Cause

COVID-19: Caused by one virus, the novel 2019 coronavirus, now called severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, or SARS-CoV-2.

Flu: Caused by any of several different types and strains of influenza viruses.

Transmission

While both the flu and COVID-19 may be transmitted in similar ways, there is also a possible difference: COVID-19 might be spread through the airborne route, meaning that tiny droplets remaining in the air could cause disease in others even after the ill person is no longer near.

Antiviral Medications

COVID-19: Antiviral medications are currently being tested to see if they can address symptoms.

Flu: Antiviral medications can address symptoms and sometimes shorten the duration of the illness.

Vaccine

COVID-19: No vaccine is available at this time, though it is in progress.

Flu: A vaccine is available and effective to prevent some of the most dangerous types or to reduce the severity of the flu.

Find out more about deaths and infections from Johns Hopkins Medicine.
answerText:
Influenza (flu) and COVID-19 are both contagious respiratory illnesses, but they are caused by different viruses. COVID-19 is caused by infection with a new coronavirus (called SARS-CoV-2) and flu is caused by infection with influenza viruses.
Because some of the symptoms of flu and COVID-19 are similar, it may be hard to tell the difference between them based on symptoms alone, and testing may be needed to help confirm a diagnosis. Flu and COVID-19 share many characteristics, but there are some key differences between the two:

COVID-19 seems to spread more easily than flu and causes more serious illnesses in some people.
It can take longer before people show symptoms of COVID-19, and people can be contagious with the COVID-19 virus for longer.

Doctors and scientists are working to estimate the death rate of COVID-19, but currently, it is thought to be substantially higher (possibly 10 times or more) than that of most strains of the flu.
Find more information about the differences and similarities between flu and COVID-19 from the CDC.
Itâs more important than ever to get your flu shot this year, when flu viruses and the new coronavirus may be spreading at the same time. Learn more about the flu and find a flu shot.
Find out more about what Vermont is doing to prepare for a COVID-19 vaccine.
There are things you can do to keep from getting or spreading the flu and COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.

questionOriginal: Are face masks or coverings required in Vermont?
questionText: Are face masks or coverings required in Vermont?
answerOriginal:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part your household. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces and group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).

Face masks or coverings are not required when you are doing strenuous exercise or activities. They are also not required for â and should not be worn by:

  • Children under the age of 2
  • Anyone who has trouble breathing
  • Anyone who is unable to remove the face mask without assistance
  • Anyone who has a medical or behavioral reason for not wearing a face mask

If you have a medical or developmental condition or have trouble breathing, you are not required to show evidence or documentation of your condition.

Businesses and other entities may also post signage explaining their mask requirements and can deny entry or service to people who do not to wear a mask.

Wearing face masks or coverings helps keep people from spreading the virus. This is because the virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms.

In addition to wearing cloth face masks or coverings, everyone should keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19 and face coverings for children.

questionOriginal: When will I receive my test results?
questionText: When will I receive my test results?
answerOriginal:
Test results will be available typically within 1 to 3 days.

How you receive results varies depending on where you were tested.

If you were tested at a Health Department popup testing site (for people without symptoms), you will get a call from the Health Department when your results are ready, which is usually within 2 to 4 days, if not sooner. You will also get a letter in the mail within 7 days of being tested. Health Department tests sites are listed here.

If you got tested anywhere else, the Health Department cannot provide your results. Please contact your health care provider if they ordered the test, or the facility that conducted the test.

If you received a positive result, the Health Department will also reach out to talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.
answerText:
Test results will be available typically within 3 business days. Find out what to do while youâre waiting for your test results.
How you receive results varies depending on where you were tested.
If you were tested at a Health Department testing site (for people without symptoms) and:

you requested an electronic result, you can expect an email within 3 business days, when your result is ready. You can thenÂ log in to your COVID-19 testing accountÂ to get the result. You will not receive a letter.
you requested a letter, you can expect to receive it within 7 business days. If you also provided an email address, you can expect an email within 3 business days, when your result is ready.Â You can thenÂ log in to your COVID-19 testing accountÂ to get the result.

The Health Department only uses a PCR test.Â We cannot guarantee that you will receive your results in less than 3 business days. We also cannot accommodate special requests for receiving test results. Find the list of Health Department test sites.
If you have a positive result, our contact tracing team will talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.
If you got tested anywhere else, the Health Department cannot provide your results. Please contact your health care provider if they ordered the test, or the facility that conducted the test.
If you were tested before an inpatient or outpatient procedure, you will receive your test results before your procedure from the health care provider who is doing the procedure.
If you received a positive result, the Health Department will also reach out to talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.

questionOriginal: How is a sample collected for COVID-19 testing?
questionText: How is a sample collected for COVID-19 testing?
answerOriginal:
Usually a health care provider collects samples (specimens) from you in one of two ways, but there are other options:

  1. The health care provider collects a nasal, or nasopharyngeal (NP) swab. This is when a dry swab is inserted through one nostril and is rubbed against the back of your nose and throat.
  2. The health care provider collects a sample from the front of your nose with a dry swab.
answerText:
Usually, samples (specimens) are collected from you in one of two ways:

Nasal swab - this is a short, dry swab that is used to collect a sample from the front of your nose. This type of test is used at the Health Departmentâs testing sites. It is also used for certain priority groups, including children.
Nasopharyngeal or NP swab â this is a long, dry swab that is inserted through one nostril and is rubbed against the back of your nose and throat.

questionOriginal: Can my spouse or partner get a COVID-19 vaccine if they are younger than 75?
questionText: Can my spouse or partner get a COVID-19 vaccine if they are younger than 75?
answerOriginal:
No. Only people who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont may make an appointment. Your spouse or partner will be able to get their vaccine as soon as their age group is eligible. People who are 70 years and older will be the next eligible age group.

Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

questionOriginal: Do I have to be a Vermont resident to get the COVID-19 vaccine?
questionText: Do I have to be a Vermont resident to get the COVID-19 vaccine?
answerOriginal:
Yes. You will need to provide your address to make an appointment for the COVID-19 vaccine. However, if you live in another state, you can still get a vaccine in Vermont if:

  • You work in Vermont.
  • Your primary health care provider is in Vermont.
  • You moved to Vermont within the last 6 months with the intention of becoming a resident.

Identification is not required to make or go to a vaccine appointment.

People who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont are now eligible to get a vaccine. Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

questionOriginal: How will I know when I can get my vaccine?
questionText: How will I know when I can get my vaccine?
answerOriginal:
In the current phase, people who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont are eligible to get a vaccine.

In Phase 1A, health care workers and long-term care residents and staff are being notified directly about when and where they can get vaccinated. Because vaccine supply fluctuates, at this time health care personnel may have to wait for the next opportunity when there is more vaccine available. Check with your local hospital for updates.

In addition to Health Department communications, we will work with partners such as health care practices, pharmacies, employers, and local news media to announce how people who are eligible can make an appointment.

The Health Department is not keeping a list of eligible people. As each group becomes eligible, we will announce when those people can register for appointments. In addition to Health Department communications, we will work with partners such as health care practices, pharmacies, employers, and local news media to announce additional groups who become eligible for the vaccine.

Because vaccine supply fluctuates, at this time health care personnel may have to wait for the next opportunity when there is more vaccine available. Check with your local hospital for updates.
In addition to Health Department communications, we will work with partners such as health care practices, pharmacies, employers, and local news media to announce how people who are eligible can make an appointment.

In addition to Health Department communications, we will work with partners such as health care practices, pharmacies, employers, and local news media to announce additional groups who become eligible for the vaccine.

questionOriginal: When will the next group be eligible for a vaccine?
questionText: When will the next group be eligible for a vaccine?
answerOriginal: We still have a very limited number of doses we receive each week. The number we receive each week can change. Vaccinations for those who are age 75 and older will begin on January 27 and include about 49,000 Vermonters. This will likely take about 6 weeks or more to complete. Because this estimate is based on the number of doses we receive, it could change.

questionOriginal: Who will be eligible next?
questionText: Who will be eligible next?
answerOriginal:
In addition to ongoing vaccination of health care workers and residents and staff of long-term care facilities, Vermont is usingÂ age groupingsÂ to determine who can receive the vaccine next based on our primary goal with vaccination efforts â to save lives.

Currently, only those age 75 and older are eligible to receive the vaccine. There are no exceptions based on age, chronic condition, circumstances of employment, or any other factor. In the weeks and months to come, age-based criteria will expand to include those age 70 and older, followed by those age 65 and older. When that population has been vaccinated, Vermonters with specific chronic conditions will be included.

After the age groups, the vaccine will be available to people in Vermont who have certain high-risk health conditions. These are medical conditions that put them at increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19 as identified by the CDC. These are:

  • Current cancer
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • COPD, also called emphysema
  • Heart conditions, such as heart failure, coronary artery disease, or cardiomyopathies
  • Immunocompromised state (weakened immune system)
  • Severe obesity
  • Pregnancy
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Down Syndrome
  • Sickle cell disease

Stay tuned to our website for updates on the next phases.

questionOriginal: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
questionText: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
answerOriginal:
The best way to prevent yourself and others from getting sick with COVID-19 is to avoid being exposed to the virus. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Everyone should:

  • Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after being in a public place, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.

  • If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Cover all surfaces of your hands and rub them together until they feel dry.

  • Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.

  • Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.

  • Avoid close contact with people who are sick.

  • Wear a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

  • Stay home when you are sick.

  • Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the inside of your elbow. Throw used tissues in the trash. Then immediately wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

  • Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily.

Learn more about COVID-19 prevention and how to protect yourself and others.
answerText:
The virus is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person. Here is how you can protect yourself from getting COVID-19 and from spreading it to others:

Stay home and away from others if you are sick.
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol, especially after being in a public place, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with. If you are around other people, itâs safest to be outdoors.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.
Have the âCOVID Talkâ with people before you make plans and share what you need to feel safe and comfortable.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Avoid crowded indoor spaces.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the inside of your elbow. Throw the tissue in the trash and wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily.
Limit your travel. Check Vermont's travel guidance, and read CDC's guidance on travel in the United States.

Learn more:

Preventing COVID-19
Daily activities and going out

How to protect yourself and others

questionOriginal: Can I register to get the COVID-19 vaccine now? How do I sign up?
questionText: Can I register to get the COVID-19 vaccine now? How do I sign up?
answerOriginal:
The current phase of vaccination is only for people who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont. Appointments are required, and clinics won't be able to accept walk-ins.

You will need to create an account in the registration system first, and then log in to schedule your appointment. You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address.

If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The registration system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system. Even if youâre not currently eligible to get a vaccine, you can set up an account ahead of time.

Find out what you will need and how to make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine. You can also watch a video on how to make your appointment online.

questionOriginal: Can I make a vaccine appointment for someone else? How do I sign someone up as a dependent?
questionText: Can I make a vaccine appointment for someone else? How do I sign someone up as a dependent?
answerOriginal:
Yes, you can make an appointment for your loved one or someone you care for who is 75 years or older, especially if they need help registering online.

If you are making an appointment online for a spouse or partner at the same time as your own, you will need to make the appointments individually. Learn more about making two appointments at the same time.

If you are a case worker who is scheduling an appointment for your client, please call 855-722-7878 Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.

If you are scheduling an appointment for a family member, we recommend that you create an account, and then sign them up as a âdependent.â

First, you need to create an account in the registration system. You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address.

If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The registration system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system. If you already have an account, go to the âadding them as a dependentâ steps below.

Here is how you create an account:

  • Go to the COVID-19 Event Portal.
  • Enter your name, phone number, email address, and date of birth.
  • Click the âcreate accountâ button.

After you create an account, an email is immediately sent to the email address you entered. You will need to verify your account on the COVID-19 Event Portal to make the personâs appointment:

  • Click on the link in the email sent to you to verify your account.
  • Enter your Patient ID number.
  • Create a password.
  • Review and consent to the Notice of Privacy Practices.
  • Enter your personal information.

Next, you need to add them as a dependent. Click on the âAdd Dependent/Spouseâ button at the top of the screen. After consenting, you will need to enter their personal information:

  • Name
  • Email address (use your email, the same one used to set up your account)
  • Phone number
  • Date of birth
  • Address

If the person getting the vaccine does not live in Vermont, the system will ask do they work in Vermont, get primary care in Vermont, or recently moved to Vermont. If none of these apply, they wonât be able to get vaccinated in Vermont, and should seek a vaccine in the state where they live.

Then, click the âSchedule Vaccine Appointmentâ button at the top of the screen and select their name. Select a clinic site location by searching by county and date range.

Next, you will answer a series of medical (see below) and demographic questions as well as questions about any COVID-19 symptoms the person has. You will be asked to provide their health insurance information. Insurance is not required, and there is no cost for getting the vaccine. You will be asked to complete a waiver.

Finally, choose an appointment slot from the list of available appointments. Click the âsubmitâ button. You will immediately receive an email confirmation.

These are the medical screening questions asked:

  1. Have you ever had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine or injectable therapy, an immediate allergic reaction of any severity to a previous dose of an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine or any of its components (including polyethylene glycol [PEG]), or an immediate allergic reaction of any severity to polysorbate? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get any of the currently available COVID-19 vaccines. They should consider contacting their health care provider if they have questions.
  2. Are you currently sick with COVID-19 or still in your isolation period following a COVID-19 infection? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a COVID-19 vaccine at this time, but can schedule an appointment at a later date.
  3. Have you received another vaccine in the last 14 days? If the answer is yes, then they won't be able to schedule an appointment right now, but can log back in at a later date to schedule an appointment.
  4. Do you have a weakened immune system caused by something such as HIV infection or cancer or do you take immunosuppressive drugs or therapies? If the answer is yes, then they can make an appointment but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
  5. Do you have a history of a bleeding disorder or are you taking a blood thinner? If the answer is yes, then they can still get a vaccine, but they may want to talk with their health care provider first about any concerns. People with bleeding disorders or who are taking blood thinners may bruise or have more serious bleeding after injections. Special precautions can be taken to help avoid post-injection bleeding and bruising, such as using a very fine needle and applying pressure to the injection site after the injection.
  6. Are you pregnant? If the answer is yes, then they can make an appointment but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
  7. Are you breastfeeding or lactating? If the answer is yes, then they can make an appointment but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
  8. Have you received passive antibody therapy as treatment for COVID-19 in the past 90 days? If the answer is yes, then they will need to wait for 90 days before scheduling an appointment.

You can also watch a video on how to make an appointment online.

questionOriginal: Can I make two appointments for COVID-19 vaccination at the same time, for example for both my parents or myself and my spouse?
questionText: Can I make two appointments for COVID-19 vaccination at the same time, for example for both my parents or myself and my spouse?
answerOriginal:
You will need to register each person individually. We can only register one person for an appointment at a time online and through the call center. This is because each slot and series of questions apply just to one person.

If you are making an appointment online, you can either create an account for each person, or create a single account and add the other person to the account by clicking on the âAdd Dependent/Spouseâ button at the top of the screen (follow the prompts in the registration system). You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address. Find out what you will need and how to make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

If you are making an appointment by phone, you can also make more than one appointment. We will do our best to get the appointments as close together as possible, but they may not be at the same time. Call 855-722-7878 Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.

questionOriginal: What do owners of lodging facilities need to do?
questionText: What do owners of lodging facilities need to do?
answerOriginal:
As of March 30, Governor Scott ordered all lodging facilities to close, except for exemptions when supporting the stateâs COVID-19 response. Lodging facilities include hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts, inns, short term rentals (for example, VRBO, Homeaway, Airbnb, etc.), and all public and private camping facilities and RV parks.

Governor Scott announced on April 10 that lodging operators may accept new reservations for stays and events occurring on June 15 or later. However, if the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order is extended, they will need to rebook.

All reservations between May 15 and May 22 need to be canceled. All reservations from out-of-state guests who cannot first meet the mandatory 14-day quarantine requirements must also be canceled through June 15. This date may be changed or extended.

Find up-to-date guidance for lodging and accommodations from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD).

Businesses must follow mandatory health and safety requirements that requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.

Read the COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses and find more resources for food and lodging businesses.

The Vermont State Police and local law enforcement will monitor lodging providers for compliance and work with the Attorney Generalâs Office on additional compliance measures if needed. Learn about guidance on enforcement of the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order from the Vermont Department of Public Safety.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.
answerText:
Lodging operations, short-term rentals, campgrounds and marinas may accept overnight reservations from Vermont residents and out-of-state guests who have met the quarantine requirement.
Lodging operators should recommend that all out-of-state guests sign up with Sara Alert once arriving in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.
Find details on the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:

Up-to-date phased restart guidance for lodging, campgrounds and other accommodations. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face masks or coverings over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.
Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses

Read the COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses and find more resources for food and lodging businesses from the Health Department.
Find out what to do if a guest or visitor at your establishment tests positive for COVID-19 from the Health Department.
The Vermont State Police and local law enforcement will continue to do compliance checks at lodging establishments.
The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

questionOriginal: Which vaccine should I get? Will I have a choice?
questionText: Which vaccine should I get? Will I have a choice?
answerOriginal:
Both the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are more than 94% effective with similar side effects. Side effects are a normal way that your body builds immunity to COVID-19.

Which vaccine you get will most likely be based on which vaccine is available at your appointment. As time goes on, you may have a choice, especially if ongoing studies determine if one is better for certain people, like for children.

For your second dose, you should get the same vaccine as your first dose. When you are at your first vaccine appointment, someone will help you schedule an appointment to get your second dose of vaccine. You will also be given a card with the name of the vaccine you received when you get your first shot. If you have a smartphone, you may want to take a picture of the card in case you misplace it.

questionOriginal: Why canât children and adolescents get the COVID-19 vaccine?
questionText: Why canât children and adolescents get the COVID-19 vaccine?
answerOriginal:
Childrenâs immune systems are different at different ages. They are also different from adults. This means that the vaccine studies need to be repeated with children. Both Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna have started vaccine trials with children as young as age 12. If the trials are successful, there will be the usual review processes before the vaccines can be approved for emergency use and then produced for distribution. This process can take a while, especially for very young ages, which are usually tested last.

The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is authorized for people 16 years and older. The Moderna vaccine is authorized for people 18 years and older.

questionOriginal: What protections are in place for congregate care settings and long-term care facilities?
questionText: What protections are in place for congregate care settings and long-term care facilities?
answerOriginal:
The Health Department has contacted all long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities proactively to review strategies to prevent COVID-19 infection and develop plans to respond immediately if an infection is identified. We complete an in-depth assessment by phone and provide guidance about personal protective equipment and other infection prevention and control recommendations. We continue to stay in touch for any technical assistance needs and additional questions.

If a case of COVID-19 is associated with a long-term care facility, an epidemiology team is quickly activated. They contact the facility to provide recommendations and infection control support. The team begins contact tracing to determine the source of the infection and how it may be spreading. They ask questions and collect information to help identify anyone the patient had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than 6 feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) The team communicates with close contacts to ensure isolation and quarantine guidelines are being followed, which will differ depending on the type of setting.

Vermont is taking measures to slow the spread of COVID-19 in certain types of group living facilities, including nursing homes, assisted living facilities, residential care homes, therapeutic community residences, residential treatment centers, correctional facilities,Â state psychiatric care facilities, and homeless shelters.

If a staff member or resident tests positive for COVID-19, facility-wide testing of staff and residents might be recommended in consultation with the Health Department. If facility-wide testing is recommended, the Health Department provides technical assistance to make sure that the facility is connected with testing resources and provides guidance on when additional rounds of testing should take place. The Health Department also works closely with the facility to provide infection control guidance and resources.

Additionally, many long-term care facilities are conducting ongoing staff surveillance testing. For related guidance, read the Long Term Care Guidance for Operations During COVID-19 Health Emergency from the Department of Disabilities, Aging and Independent Living (DAIL) and Testing Recommendations for Long-term Care Facilities from the Health Department.

There is a table showing active outbreaks in long-term care facilities, which is updated on Tuesdays and Fridays.

Residents and staff of group living facilities and new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine period first.

The Health Department has contacted all long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities proactively to review strategies to prevent COVID-19 infection and develop plans to respond immediately if an infection is identified. We complete an in-depth assessment by phone and provide guidance about personal protective equipment and other infection prevention and control recommendations. We continue to stay in touch for any technical assistance needs and additional questions.
If a case of COVID-19 is associated with a long-term care facility, an epidemiology team is quickly activated. They contact the facility to provide recommendations and infection control support. The team begins contact tracing to determine the source of the infection and how it may be spreading. They ask questions and collect information to help identify anyone the patient had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than 6 feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) The team communicates with close contacts to ensure isolation and quarantine guidelines are being followed, which will differ depending on the type of setting.
Vermont is taking measures to slow the spread of COVID-19 in certain types of group living facilities, including nursing homes, assisted living facilities, residential care homes, therapeutic community residences, residential treatment centers, correctional facilities,Â state psychiatric care facilities, and homeless shelters.
If a staff member or resident tests positive for COVID-19, facility-wide testing of staff and residents might be recommended in consultation with the Health Department. If facility-wide testing is recommended, the Health Department provides technical assistance to make sure that the facility is connected with testing resources and provides guidance on when additional rounds of testing should take place. The Health Department also works closely with the facility to provide infection control guidance and resources.
Additionally, many long-term care facilities are conducting ongoing staff surveillance testing. For related guidance, read the Long Term Care Guidance for Operations During COVID-19 Health Emergency from the Department of Disabilities, Aging and Independent Living (DAIL) and Testing Recommendations for Long-term Care Facilities from the Health Department.
There is a table showing active outbreaks in long-term care facilities, which is updated on Tuesdays and Fridays.
Residents and staff of group living facilities and new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine period first.

questionOriginal: When do I need to get my second shot?
questionText: When do I need to get my second shot?
answerOriginal:
The COVID-19 vaccine is two shots, 21 or 28 days apart. Both of theÂ vaccines availableÂ are over 94% effective withÂ two doses. Doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine are given 21 days apart, and doses of the Moderna vaccine are given 28 days apart.

For the vaccine to be the most effective and help prevent you from getting COVID-19, you should get your second shot as close to the recommended time interval. If you miss your second dose, please get it as soon as you can.

You won't be able to make an appointment for your second dose until you get your first dose. Before you leave your first dose appointment, clinic staff will help you makeÂ an appointment to get the second dose.

questionOriginal: What are the ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines?
questionText: What are the ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines?
answerOriginal:
The ingredients in the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines are similar to what is found in other vaccines â both contain the mRNA protein, fats, salts, and sugars. They do not have any fetal tissue, animal products, eggs, gelatin, latex, or preservatives in them.

questionOriginal: Should I get the vaccine if I have a medical condition?
questionText: Should I get the vaccine if I have a medical condition?
answerOriginal:
In clinical studies, COVID-19 vaccines were just as effective for people with and without medical conditions. In fact, people with some conditions are more likely to get very sick if they get COVID-19, so getting vaccinated could be even more important. If you are unsure if you should get the vaccine, talk to your health care provider about any conditions you have. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.

Learn more about vaccination if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.

Read the health screening questions asked before you get the vaccine.

questionOriginal: Should I be vaccinated if I have or had COVID-19?
questionText: Should I be vaccinated if I have or had COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you had COVID-19 and are recovered, you may be vaccinated or choose to defer for up to 90 days. Evidence suggests that getting infected again in 90 days after is uncommon.

If you currently have COVID-19, please wait until you have recovered before being vaccinated.

If you had monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma as part of COVID-19 treatment, wait for at least 90 days before getting your vaccination to avoid interfering with your treatment.

If you currently have COVID-19, please wait until you have recovered before being vaccinated.
If you had monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma as part of COVID-19 treatment, wait for at least 90 days before getting your vaccination to avoid interfering with your treatment.

questionOriginal: Iâve received two doses of the vaccine. Do I still need to wear a mask, avoid close contact with others, and quarantine?
questionText: Iâve received two doses of the vaccine. Do I still need to wear a mask, avoid close contact with others, and quarantine?
answerOriginal:
Yes. People who get the vaccine should continue taking steps to prevent COVID-19. It takes time for the vaccine to train your body to fight COVID-19, so you may not be protected by the vaccine until a few weeks after your second dose. While the vaccine protects you from illness, we donât yet know if you can unknowingly spread the virus after you get vaccinated. Until enough people are vaccinated and we know more, we need to follow all safety guidelines like wearing masks, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing our hands.

Even if you have gotten the vaccine, you must quarantine when you travel or return to Vermont under the current travel guidelines. Also, you are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with under the current social gathering guidelines.

It will take a while for everyone to be vaccinated. Together, the vaccine and those preventive actions are the best ways to keep from getting and spreading COVID-19.

questionOriginal: I am pregnant or breastfeeding. Should I get vaccinated?
questionText: I am pregnant or breastfeeding. Should I get vaccinated?
answerOriginal:
Based on how mRNA vaccines work, experts believe they are unlikely to pose a specific risk for people who are pregnant. However, the actual risks of mRNA vaccines to the pregnant person and their fetus are unknown because these vaccines have not been studied in pregnant people. Pregnant people have a slightly higher risk for poor outcomes, as do their fetuses, with COVID-19 infection. Studies are on-going.

If you are pregnant and part of a group that is recommended to receive the vaccine (for example, health care personnel), you may choose to be vaccinated. The CDC and other professional organizations recommend that you consult with your health care provider.

There are no data on the safety of COVID-19 vaccines in people who are breastfeeding or the effects of mRNA vaccines on milk production/excretion or on the breastfed baby. mRNA vaccines are not thought to be a risk to the breastfed baby. A person who is breastfeeding and is part of a group recommended to receive a COVID-19 vaccine (for example, health care personnel) may choose to be vaccinated.
