questionOriginal: How much does the COVID-19 vaccine cost?
questionText: How much does the COVID-19 vaccine cost?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 vaccines are free. COVID-19 vaccines are provided to Vermonters at no cost, even if you donât have health insurance. The provider that gives you your vaccine may charge an administrative fee to your insurance, but you are guaranteed a COVID-19 vaccine without paying a fee.

questionOriginal: How do I know if my symptoms are from the vaccine or sickness from COVID-19?
questionText: How do I know if my symptoms are from the vaccine or sickness from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
It takes time for the vaccine to teach your body to fight COVID-19, so you may not be protected by the vaccine until a few weeks after your second dose. This is one of the reasons it is so important to continue prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, even after youâve been vaccinated.

It may be hard to tell the difference between side effects from the vaccine and symptoms from sickness if you get infected with COVID-19 between vaccine doses. While everyoneâs reaction may be different, vaccine side effects usually start within 12 to 24 hours after your vaccination. They should go away within a few days.

If symptoms get worse or last longer than a few days, contact your health care provider. They should be able to suggest next steps and maybe a COVID-19 test. Getting the vaccine will not affect your COVID-19 test results.

questionOriginal: Where can I find the most current information about the COVID-19 vaccine in Vermont?
questionText: Where can I find the most current information about the COVID-19 vaccine in Vermont?
answerOriginal:
Stay up to date on COVID-19 vaccination in Vermont, including who can get the vaccine now and who will be eligible next. Check back often as we update this page regularly. And sign up for our Weekly COVID-19 Update Email to stay up to date.

While we wait for the vaccine to become more widely available to Vermonters, we all must continue to keep up our prevention practices, which are still the best protection from getting and spreading COVID-19:

  • Stay home if you are sick.
  • Wash your hands often.
  • Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
  • Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
  • Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

The Health Department also strongly recommends that everyone age 6 months and older get their flu shot. The flu vaccine is available in your doctorâs office and at pharmacies around the state. This will help prevent the potential harm of getting the flu and COVID-19 â at the same time or in succession. Learn more about the flu and find a flu shot.

questionOriginal: Am I eligible to get the COVID-19 vaccine? Can I get on a list?
questionText: Am I eligible to get the COVID-19 vaccine? Can I get on a list?
answerOriginal:
People who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont are now eligible to get a vaccine. Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

Health care workers and long-term care residents and staff are being notified directly about when and where they can get vaccinated. Because vaccine supply fluctuates, at this time health care personnel may have to wait for the next opportunity when there is more vaccine available. Check with your local hospital for updates.

If you are eligible, talk with your health care provider if you've had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine, injectable therapy, or polysorbate, or if you have questions about whether getting the vaccine is right for you because of health conditions, allergies, or other vaccines you've received recently. Read the health screening questions asked before you get the vaccine.

The Health Department is not keeping a list of eligible people. When there is enough vaccine available, we will be announcing when Vermonters can register for appointments and who is eligible. In addition to Health Department communications, we will work with partners such as health care practices, pharmacies, employers, and local news media to announce additional groups who become eligible for the vaccine.

Find out who will be eligible next.

questionOriginal: How do I reschedule or cancel my vaccine appointment?
questionText: How do I reschedule or cancel my vaccine appointment?
answerOriginal:
It is very important that you keep the appointment you made. Please do not make an appointment if you are not sure you will be able to keep it. Cancellations and unplanned no-shows could cause the vaccine to be spoiled.

If you need to cancel your appointment, please do as soon as possible. You will need to log in to your account and cancel it there.

If you need to reschedule your appointment, call 855-722-7878. If you reschedule it online,Â youâll have to cancel your current appointment and may risk not getting an earlier one.

questionOriginal: What is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?
questionText: What is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?
answerOriginal:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part your household. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces and group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).

Wearing face masks or coverings helps keep people from spreading the virus. This is because the virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms.

In addition to wearing cloth face masks or coverings, everyone should keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.

A face mask or covering must be worn properly to be effective and avoid the spread of germs:

  • Wash your hands before putting it on.
  • Be sure your mouth and nose are covered.
  • Hook loops around your ears or tie it snugly.
  • Do not touch it or pull it down while in public.
  • Keep it on until you get home.
  • Remove it without touching your eyes, nose or mouth, then wash your hands immediately.
  • Wash it and make sure itâs completely dry before using again. Have a few on hand so you can rotate for washing.

If you feel like you are overheating and are having trouble breathing because it is hot outside, you should take off your mask, drink water, rest and seek shade or a cool place. It is important that you keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible, especially when you are not wearing a mask.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19 and face coverings for children.
answerText:
You are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces (for example, businesses, public buildings, parks), group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes), and other places where itâs not possible to stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
In private settings (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you wear a mask anytime you're around people you donât live with.
People with COVID-19 can spread the virus even if they donât have any symptoms. Masks protect others around you as well as offer some protection to you.
A mask must be worn properly to be effective and avoid spreading the virus:

Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer before putting it on.
Put it over your nose and mouth and secure it under your chin.
Make sure it fits snugly against the side of your face.
Slip the loops over your ears or tie the strings behind your head.
Do not touch it when you are wearing it.
Remove it by handling only the ear loops or ties and fold the outside corners together.
Be careful not to touch your eyes, nose or mouth, then wash your hands immediately after removing it.

Wash your mask regularly and make sure itâs completely dry before using it again. Have a few on hand so you can rotate them for washing and have enough clean ones to wear.
During hot weather, if you feel like you are overheating and are having trouble breathing because it is hot, take off your mask, drink water, rest and seek shade or a cool place. It is important that you stay at least 6 feet away from others whenever possible, especially when you are not wearing a mask.
During cold weather, change your mask when it becomes wet. Keep a spare mask to replace the wet one, and put the wet one in a plastic bag until you get home. If you need to wear a scarf, ski mask or balaclava, wear it over your mask. If you wear glasses, find a mask that fits closely over your nose or has a nose wire to help reduce fogging.
Wearing masks is one way we can help slow the spread of COVID-19 â in addition to staying at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with and other prevention steps.
Learn more:

Wearing face masks to keep COVID-19 from spreading
Face coverings for children
How to select, clean and wear your face mask

The State of Vermont is offering a limited number of free cloth face masks to the public. Find out if free cloth face masks are available in your area.

questionOriginal: Do homemade cloth face masks or coverings work?
questionText: Do homemade cloth face masks or coverings work?
answerOriginal:
As the state continues to reopen, it is more important than ever to make wearing cloth face masks or coverings a habit and to bring one with you whenever you leave home. Cloth face masks or coverings need to be worn in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, visiting a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

Wearing a homemade cloth face mask or covering can offer some protection to others. This is because people may be infected with COVID-19 and not show symptoms for up to two days (48 hours). The cloth face mask or covering can contain respiratory droplets and prevent them from spreading to others.

While health care workers may be able to use homemade cloth face masks or coverings as a last resort, medical-grade masks are considered personal protective equipment. These should be reserved for health care workers.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19.
answerText:
You are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces (for example, businesses, public buildings, parks), group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes), and other places where itâs not possible to stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
In private settings (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you wear a mask anytime you're around people you donât live with.
People with COVID-19 can spread the virus through respiratory droplets produced when they cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe. They can spread the virus even if they donât have any symptoms. Masks are a simple barrier to help prevent your respiratory droplets from reaching others. Studies show that masks reduce the spray of droplets when worn over your nose and mouth.
A mask also offers some protection to you,Â too. How well it protects you from breathing in the virus likely depends on the fabrics used and how your mask is made (for example, the type of fabric, the number of layers of fabric, how well the mask fits).
Find out which fabrics are best to use for cloth masks.

questionOriginal: How can we make holiday celebrations safer?
questionText: How can we make holiday celebrations safer?
answerOriginal:
To slow the spread of COVID-19, Vermonters are not allowed to gather with anyone you donât live with. We know how hard it is to be apart from family and friends who we usually celebrate holidays with. Hereâs what you need to know:

  • Staying home and with people you live with is still the lowest risk.
  • If you do gather with people you donât live with, then you should quarantine after the gathering.
  • The Health Department strongly encourages getting tested as soon as possible after the gathering and then again on day 7.
  • The Health Department strongly advises against travel, even within Vermont. All travel to and from Vermont requires quarantine (unless itâs considered essential travel).

Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for 14 days. If you have not hadÂ symptoms of COVID-19, you have theÂ optionÂ to get a PCR test on day 7Â and end your quarantine with a negative test result.

Any time you are around others, remember to add these things: 6-Foot Spaces, Masks on Faces, Uncrowded Places. Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. The more layers there are, the safer everyone will be. Learn more about COVID-19 prevention steps.

Remember, the virus can spread easily among family and friends â because they are the ones we are often in close contact with â when they donât know they have it. Like other aspects of our lives, holidays will look different and we need to do everything we can to keep each other safe.

Find information for communities of faith.

Find more tips from the CDC:

  • Holiday celebrations
  • Hosting gatherings or cook-outs
  • Attending an event or gathering

questionOriginal: Can I buy or sign a long-term lease (more than 30 days) for a new apartment or house?
questionText: Can I buy or sign a long-term lease (more than 30 days) for a new apartment or house?
answerOriginal:
Long-term rental leases are allowed. Moving and moving services are also allowed, so long as social distancing guidelines are followed. More housing information is available at the Agency of Commerce and Community Development's (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Resource Recovery Center.

Real estate services, including real estate firms, brokerages, attorneys or individuals, must conduct as much work as possible remotely to minimize in-person contact. Real estate and related services (such as title searches, appraisals, and home inspections) are allowed to begin limited operations again. Find details and up-to-date information on real estate from the ACCD.
answerText:
Long-term rental leases are allowed. Moving and moving services are also allowed, as long as people stay at least 6 feet from people they donât live with. You are also required to wear a face mask or covering anytime you are around people you donât live with. More housing information is available at the Agency of Commerce and Community Development's (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Resource Recovery Center.
Out-of-state buyers and renters must follow the travel and quarantine requirements before coming to Vermont to visit a property. People moving to Vermont for work must also follow the quarantine requirements.
Real estate and related services (such as title searches, appraisals, and home inspections) are operating under certain health and safety requirements including staying at least 6 feet away from others and wearing face masks or coverings.
Find more details and up-to-date information on real estate from the ACCD.

questionOriginal: Can I get together with friends and family?
questionText: Can I get together with friends and family?
answerOriginal:
On May 6, the Governor announced Play Smart and Play Safe: Restart VT Phase 5, which gives Vermonters a chance to reunite and enjoy each otherâs company. This allows Vermonters to leave home to get fresh air and exercise and to resume limited social interactions and gatherings of 10 or fewer people, preferably in outdoor settings, as long as health and safety precautions are taken. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

Members of one household may choose to socialize â and allow children to play â with members of another trusted household, such as family, neighbors or friends. A trusted household is one that has taken seriously the importance of social distancing and proper hygiene in their day-to-day lives. By carefully limiting these closer social interactions at this time it will be easier to identify who else may have been exposed and need to self-isolate in case someone becomes sick.

To keep COVID-19 from spreading, we must continue to:

  • Stay home and away from others if you are sick with COVID-19, have recently been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, or just donât feel well.

  • Keep a 6-foot distance from others when you meet people outside of your household.

  • Wash your hands frequently (hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol is acceptable when soap and water are not available).

  • Cough and sneeze into your elbow (even if you are wearing a cloth face mask or covering).

  • Wear a cloth face mask or covering over your nose and mouth.

Older adults (age 65 and over), and people with underlying medical conditions, like heart and lung disease or diabetes, are more likely to develop severe illness. They should continue to stay home, and family and friends should do everything they can to help keep them safe.
answerText:
As of November 14, 2020, you are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. This includes all inside and outside social and entertainment gatherings, and in public and private spaces. Learn more about what this means.
If you do gather with people you donât live with, you should quarantine. Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for 14 days. The Health Department strongly encourages you to get tested as soon as possible after the gathering and then again on day 7. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
If you are around other people, itâs safest to be outdoors. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19.
Follow these general prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.
Also, consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of the virus.
The risk for severe illness increases with age and is higher for older adults and people of any age with certain underlying medical conditions. They should consider taking additional steps to limit their risk, stay close to home, and family and friends should do everything they can to help keep them safe.
Learn more from the CDC:

Hosting gatherings or cook-outs
Attending an event or gathering

questionOriginal: What is self-observation?
questionText: What is self-observation?
answerOriginal:
Self-observation is for other Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19. Follow these prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

These are things you can do to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

  • Stay home if you are sick.
  • Wash your hands often.
  • Keep your social circle small.
  • Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
  • Wear a mask when youâre outside and canât keep 6 feet apart or anytime youâre inside with people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things and about isolation, quarantine and self-observation.

questionOriginal: I take care of someone who is in isolation because they tested positive for COVID-19, but I canât avoid close contact with them. Do I need to quarantine?
questionText: I take care of someone who is in isolation because they tested positive for COVID-19, but I canât avoid close contact with them. Do I need to quarantine?
answerOriginal: Yes. In situations where you cannot avoid close contact with someone with COVID-19, you should stay home and away from other people while the person you are caring for is sick. You should also quarantine for 14 days after they are able to end home isolation. Learn more about living with someone who has COVID-19 and cannot avoid close contact (Scenario 4).
answerText:
Yes. In situations where you cannot avoid close contact with someone with COVID-19, you should quarantine while the person you are caring for is sick. You should also quarantine for 14 days after they are able to end home isolation.
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from other people. Quarantine means you need to stay home and away from other people for 14 days since the day you were potentially exposed. You should separate yourself from others and check yourself for symptoms. Learn about the option to be tested to end quarantine after 7 days.
Find tips on what to do when a household member is sick with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
questionText: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
answerOriginal:
Anyone currently under quarantine who is not a health care worker or a correctional worker, and who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required.

This includes:

  • people returning to Vermont (for example, those who spend winter outside of Vermont, second homeowners and college students)

  • visitors coming into Vermont

  • close contacts of people who have tested positive

For anyone coming into Vermont, Day 0 is the day you arrive in Vermont.

Health care workers and correctional workers must complete the full 14-day quarantine.

You can end your quarantine period only if:

  • You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period.

  • You are tested on Day 7 or later.

  • You remain in quarantine until the result comes back.

  • You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms.

However, you must continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days and isolate at home immediately if symptoms develop.
answerText:
If you are currently under quarantine and have had no symptoms of COVID-19 during the first seven days of quarantine, you have the option to be tested and end your quarantine early. The test must be a PCR test.
You can end your quarantine period before 14 days only if:

You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period;
You are tested on day 7 or later;
You remain in quarantine until the result comes back;
You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms; and
You continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days.

If you develop symptoms at any point during your quarantine, contact your health care provider and the Health Department right away.
There are a variety of testing options available to you: your health care provider, pharmacies and Health Department testing sites. Find out where to get tested.
If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
For travelers who are completing quarantine in their home state, your home state may offer testing for people without symptoms. Continue to quarantine until you travel to Vermont.
You must quarantine even if you had COVID-19, received a positive antibody test, or got a COVID-19 vaccine. Learn more about why.
Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by day 7. This is why there is the option for people to be tested on day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine.
Residents and staff of group living facilities (for example long-term care facilities or corrections facilities) and new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine.

questionOriginal: I want to travel to Vermont from a foreign country. Is that allowed?
questionText: I want to travel to Vermont from a foreign country. Is that allowed?
answerOriginal:
If you are not a U.S. citizen, check the CDCâs travel page for advisories for travelers who are prohibited from entering the U.S.

Once you arrive in Vermont, you must quarantine for 14 days. You have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.

Find out about travel from Canada.
answerText:
All travel to and from Vermont now requires quarantine. The only exception is essential travel. The Health Department and the CDC strongly recommend not traveling right now.
If you are not a U.S. citizen, check the CDCâs travel page for advisories for travelers who are prohibited from entering the U.S. Also check the CDCâs guidance on testing and international travel.
Once you arrive in Vermont, you must quarantine for 14 days. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
Find out about travel from Canada.

questionOriginal: Do I need to quarantine if I do a short trip (day trip)?
questionText: Do I need to quarantine if I do a short trip (day trip)?
answerOriginal: People who regularly commute to or from Vermont do not need to quarantine.Â In addition, people who live near a border and regularly travel to and from a neighboring state may make day trips to that state for essential work, health care, and other essential needs like groceries or visitation for parental shared custody without quarantining. For anyone else making a day trip to or from Vermont, read the cross-state travel guidance from theÂ Agency of Commerce and Community Development.
answerText:
If you live near a state border and regularly travel to and from a neighboring state, you may make day trips to that state for work, health care, for students who commute daily to attend preK-12 school or college or a school-sponsored activity, and for other essential needs like groceries or visitation for parental shared custody, without quarantining.
The exemption to quarantineÂ only applies to the person under essential travel rules. It does not apply to anyone else who travels with you. For example, you travel for work and your child comes with you. Your child will need to quarantine for 14 days when you return to Vermont, but you wonât need to.
If you are traveling for leisure and go on a day trip, or travel by plane, train, bus or other means of public transportation, you must quarantine for 14 days in Vermont when you return.
Anyone who has not had symptoms of COVID-19, has the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end quarantine with a negative test result.
Find more travel and quarantine information.

questionOriginal: What is a âprobable caseâ?
questionText: What is a âprobable caseâ?
answerOriginal:
A case is considered âprobableâ if the person:

  • tested positive on an antigen test and has symptoms of COVID-19 or epidemiologic evidence, or
  • has symptoms of COVID-19 and is epidemiologically linked to a confirmed case of COVID-19.

As of December 2, probable cases are included in the number of COVID-19 cases in Vermont.

The Health Department follows the nationally recognized definition of COVID-19 cases, developed by the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists (CSTE) in April 2020. Since then, the Health Department has tracked probable cases and taken the same public health actions as if they were a confirmed case (confirmed means the person tested positive on a PCR test).

This means that contact tracers conduct interviews with people who are considered probable cases, provide isolation guidance, and their close contacts are notified to quarantine. People who are considered probable cases are also encouraged to get a follow-up PCR test. If they test positive on a follow-up PCR test, they are only included once in the total case count.

The Health Department began including probable cases in case counts to more accurately represent COVID-19 activity and because antigen testing in Vermont is increasing. The impact on the total case count is minimal. At this time, about 120 cases, or 2.8%, of total cases are probable cases. Right now, this change does not impact hospitalization or testing data.

Read the full CSTE definition of probable case.
answerText:
A case is considered âprobableâ if the person:

tested positive on an antigen test and has symptoms of COVID-19 or epidemiologic evidence, or
has symptoms of COVID-19 and is epidemiologically linked to a confirmed case of COVID-19.

As of December 2, probable cases are included in the number of COVID-19 cases in Vermont.
As of January 4, deaths among probable cases are included in the number of COVID-19 deaths in Vermont. A death among a probable case is a person who:

meets the probable case definition and has COVID-19 listed as a cause or contributing condition on their death certificate or
has COVID-19 listed as a cause or contributing condition on their death certificate.

This means that contact tracers conduct interviews with people who are considered probable cases, provide isolation guidance, and their close contacts are notified to quarantine. People who are considered probable cases are also encouraged to get a follow-up PCR test. If they test positive on a follow-up PCR test, they are only included once in the total case count.
The Health Department began including probable cases and deaths in counts to more accurately represent COVID-19 activity and because antigen testing in Vermont is increasing. Right now, this change does not impact hospitalization or testing data.

questionOriginal: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
questionText: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
People with COVID-19 have had a wide range of symptoms reported â ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. These symptoms may appear 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus:

  • Fever

  • Cough

  • Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing

  • Chills

  • Repeated shaking with chills

  • Muscle pain

  • Sore throat

  • New loss of taste or smell

You can check your symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.

Call your health care professional if you develop symptoms and ask if a test can be considered. Learn more about COVID-19.
answerText:
People with COVID-19 have had a wide range of symptoms reported â ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. Symptoms may start 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus. People with these symptoms may have COVID-19:

Fever (100.4Â°F or greater)
Cough
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Chills
Fatigue
Muscle or body aches
Headache
New loss of taste or smell
Sore throat
Congestion or runny nose
Nausea or vomiting
Diarrhea

This list does not include all possible symptoms. The CDC will continue to update the list of symptoms as more is learned. You can check your symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.
Not everyone with COVID-19 has a fever. Even mild symptoms (like a headache or dry cough) could be signs of COVID-19.
Not everyone infected with the COVID-19 virus has symptoms. People with COVID-19 who don't have any symptoms can spread the virus to other people. Learn how to protect yourself and others.
All Vermonters, even with mild symptoms, are encouraged to contact their health care provider to get tested. Your provider will test you at their office or refer you for testing nearby. Stay home while waiting for your result.
If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
Learn more about what to do if you have COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Does being vaccinated affect my COVID-19 test results?
questionText: Does being vaccinated affect my COVID-19 test results?
answerOriginal:
No. The COVID-19 vaccines that are available and the other vaccines currently in clinical trials in the United States will not cause you to test positive on viral tests. PCR and antigen tests are viral tests, and will tell you if you are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.

If your body develops an immune response, which is what happens when you get vaccinated, there is a possibility you may test positive on some antibody tests. Antibody, or serologic, tests measure the bodyâs immune response to the virus and show that you may have some level of protection against the virus. Experts are currently looking at how getting the COVID-19 vaccine may affect antibody testing results.

questionOriginal: What do I need to know about COVID-19 testing? Where can I get tested?
questionText: What do I need to know about COVID-19 testing? Where can I get tested?
answerOriginal:
You can get tested at a Health Department testing site if you live or work in Vermont and do not have symptoms. This includes children 12 months or older. Anyone under 18 should be accompanied by a parent or guardian or bring a signed parental consent form.

There are a variety of testing options available to you: your health care provider, pharmacies and Health Department testing sites. Find out where to get tested and how to schedule an appointment.

If you have symptoms of COVID-19, do not go to a testing site. Talk to your health care provider. If you don't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.

The Health Department recommends testing as soon as possible when:

  • you have symptoms of COVID-19 (call your health care provider first).
  • you are referred by your health care provider.
  • a person in your workplace or household, or a person you attended an event with, tests positive for COVID-19.
  • you plan on going to a social gathering with people you don't live with (other than recreating with one masked person outside). You should get tested before the gathering, right after, and again on day 7.

If you often gather socially with people you don't live with, you should get tested weekly.

College students returning to Vermont from out of state should quarantine and be tested on or after day 7 of quarantine after returning home.

Travelers to Vermont and Vermonters returning from out of state must follow quarantine requirements. You have the option to get a PCR test on or after day 7 of quarantine and end your quarantine early with a negative test result.

There is no cost to individuals for a PCR test for COVID-19, even if you donât have health insurance.

You may come to a Health Department testing site to get tested more than once if you have reason to be concerned about infection.

Health Department testing sites use nasal swabs. This is a self-administered test, which means that you use a short, dry swab to collect a sample from the front of your nose.

If you need a ride to the testing site, schedule your appointment first, and then call 833-387-7200 at least two days before the appointment.

Find out:

  • Where to get tested and how to schedule an appointment
  • What to expect at a Health Department testing site â including answers to more questions about testing
  • What to do while youâre waiting for test results and how to get your test results
  • When you will get your test results
  • What the different types of tests are
  • How many Vermonters have been tested â this information is updated daily.

questionOriginal: How can children stay safe and prevent the spread of COVID-19?
questionText: How can children stay safe and prevent the spread of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
As of November 14, 2020, you are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. This includes all inside and outside social, recreational and entertainment gatherings, and in public and private spaces. Learn more about what this means.

You can prevent the spread of COVID-19 by following these general prevention steps:

  • Stay home if you are sick.
  • Wash your hands often.
  • Keep your social circle small.
  • Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
  • Wear a mask (children over 2 who are able) when youâre outside and canât keep 6 feet apart or anytime youâre inside with people you donât live with.

If you are around other people, itâs safest to be outdoors. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19.

Gathering in groups or âpodsâ related to education or child care that are already formed can continue. Gathering in pods related to social activity, informal play groups, play dates, or sleepovers are not allowed at this time. New pods of any kind are discouraged. Find more guidance related to limits on multi-household social gatherings.

There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

  • 6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
  • Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
  • Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.

Children can also continue to take advantage of technology to play games or keep in touch with friends and family. These changes will continue to be difficult, but we are all doing our part to slow down this pandemic.

Learn more:

  • Resources for families with children
  • Coping with family stress during COVID-19
  • Face coverings for children
  • Frequently asked questions about school

questionOriginal: What do I do if I test positive for COVID-19?
questionText: What do I do if I test positive for COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.

If you or a family member are sick, follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and your community:

Isolate at home

  • Stay home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting your health care provider. Anyone who does not have a health care provider can call 2-1-1 to be connected to care or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.
  • Separate yourself from other people and pets**.**
  • Monitor your symptoms.
  • Wear a face mask or covering when you're around people and pets.
  • Cover your coughs and sneezes with your sleeve or a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
  • Wash your hands often. Use an alcohol-based sanitizer if soap and water aren't available.
  • Avoid sharing personal household items**.**
  • Clean all high-touch surfaces in your home daily.
  • Get support from others. Stay in touch with family and friends by phone, email or online platform.

Someone from the Health Department will contact you to ask for your help with contact tracing. Contact tracing is used to provide education, support and guidance to people who are diagnosed with an infectious disease. Itâs also used to identify people who have been in close contact with them, so they can take steps to stop the disease from spreading to others.

Learn more:

  • Caring for yourself at home from the CDC
  • 10 ways to manage respiratory symptoms at home from the CDC
  • Information on breastfeeding if you have COVID-19 from the CDC
  • What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation
  • What to do if you test positive for COVID-19
answerText:
Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.
If you or a family member are sick, follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and your community:
Isolate at home

Stay home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting your health care provider. Anyone who does not have a health care provider can call 2-1-1 to be connected to care or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.
Separate yourself from other people and pets**.**
Monitor your symptoms.
Wear a face mask or covering when you're around people and pets.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with your sleeve or a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Wash your hands often. Use an alcohol-based sanitizer if soap and water aren't available.
Avoid sharing personal household items**.**
Clean all high-touch surfaces in your home daily.
Get support from others. Stay in touch with family and friends by phone, email or online platform.

Someone from the Health Department will contact you to ask for your help with contact tracing. Contact tracing is used to provide education, support and guidance to people who are diagnosed with an infectious disease. Itâs also used to identify people who have been in close contact with them, so they can take steps to stop the disease from spreading to others.

questionOriginal: I am turning 75 soon. Can I make an appointment now?
questionText: I am turning 75 soon. Can I make an appointment now?
answerOriginal: You will have to wait until you turn 75 until you can schedule an appointment. This is because the system asks for your date of birth and only allows people who are currently 75 and older to schedule one. There will be enough vaccine appointment slots available for you to register.

questionOriginal: What kind of assistance will be available at my vaccine appointment? Can someone come with me?
questionText: What kind of assistance will be available at my vaccine appointment? Can someone come with me?
answerOriginal:
All vaccine clinics will be handicap accessible. Wheelchairs are available at all Health Department vaccination sites and at hospitals.

Language interpreters (including ASL) can be arranged at Health Department vaccination sites. Usually, the interpreter will work with you remotely by phone or video conference through a computer available at the site. To request an interpreter, ask one of the public health workers at the site. Some sites, including Burlington and Winooski, will have in-person interpreters based on demand for these services in the area.

If you need physical assistance getting to your vaccine appointment, you can have one other person come with you. You will both have your temperatures taken and will be asked questions to determine if you have any current COVID-19 symptoms. If either of you do, then the person who has symptoms wonât be allowed to go any further.

You will both need to wear masks during your appointment. If you do not have one, there will be masks available at the clinic. If you have trouble breathing, are unable to remove your mask by yourself, or have a medical reason for not wearing one, you will not be required to wear a mask.

Find out what to do if you need a ride to your appointment.

questionOriginal: What can I expect at my vaccine appointment?
questionText: What can I expect at my vaccine appointment?
answerOriginal:
You will need to wear a mask during your appointment. If you do not have one, there will be one available for you at the clinic. If you have trouble breathing, are unable to remove it yourself, or have a medical reason for not wearing one, you will not be required to wear a mask.

Remember to dress warmly for the weather.Â Arrive on time so you donât have to wait long, or keep others waiting.Â Please do not arrive earlier than 15 minutes before your appointment. If you need someone to come with you for assistance, please only bring one person so we can limit the number of people inside the clinics and make sure people are properly distanced.

Once you arrive at the vaccine clinic, here is what will happen:

  1. Before you enter the clinic, someone will take your temperature and ask questions to determine if you have any current symptoms of COVID-19. If you do, then you will be asked to reschedule your appointment.
  2. You will go inside and check in. You will be asked to fill out paperwork, which will include a health screening questionnaire.
  3. You will be asked to go to a vaccination station where you will get the vaccine in your arm.
  4. You will be given a handout with information about the vaccine you got and any possible side effects to watch out for, as well as how to report any reactions or side effects you may have.
  5. You will be asked to stay for 15 to 30 minutes so you can be watched for any side effects.
  6. Someone will help you schedule an appointment to get your second dose of vaccine at a later date.

answerOriginal: An âinconclusiveâ or âindeterminateâ result means the test was neither positive nor negative. If you receive a test result that is âinconclusiveâ or âindeterminate,â the Health Department encourages you to get retested. Find out where to get tested.

questionOriginal: I donât have my own transportation. Can I get a ride to my vaccine appointment?
questionText: I donât have my own transportation. Can I get a ride to my vaccine appointment?
answerOriginal:
Yes. Free public transportation to vaccine clinics is available to Vermont residents who do not have their own transportation. Rides are coordinated by the Vermont Public Transportation Association. Volunteer drivers will use cars, vans or buses. All rides are ADA compliant and will accommodate people living with disabilities.

Please make a request at least 48 hours before your vaccine appointment. These rides are subject to the availability of transportation resources, so advance notice is necessary to make sure you will have a ride.

Rides are only available if you are not sick with COVID-19 (with symptoms or without symptoms) or are not a close contact of someone who has COVID-19. If you recently traveled, you need to follow the current travel quarantine requirements before you can request a ride. If you fall into one of these categories, you will need to answer some questions to find out when you can use public transportation.

Find contact information for your local public transportation provider.

questionOriginal: What should pregnant or breastfeeding people do?
questionText: What should pregnant or breastfeeding people do?
answerOriginal:
We do not currently know if pregnant people have a greater chance of getting sick from COVID-19 than the general public nor whether they are more likely to have serious illness as a result. Based on available information, pregnant people seem to have the same risk as adults who are not pregnant.

Learn more from CDC about COVID-19 and pregnancy and breastfeeding.

Find more resources for families with children.
answerText:
Based on what we know at this time,Â pregnant peopleÂ are at an increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19 and death,Â compared to non-pregnant people. Additionally, pregnant people with COVID-19 might be at increased risk of other adverse outcomes, such as preterm birth (delivering the baby earlier than 37 weeks). Therefore,Â it is especially important for pregnant people, and those who live with them, to protect themselves from getting COVID-19.
We donât know for sure if people with COVID-19 can spread the virus to babies through their breast milk, but the current evidence suggests that this isnât likely.
Learn more from the CDC about COVID-19 and pregnancy and breastfeeding.
Find more resources for families with children.

questionOriginal: Can I get the virus from food?
questionText: Can I get the virus from food?
answerOriginal:
Unlike foodborne gastrointestinal (GI) viruses that often make people sick from contaminated food, COVID-19 is a virus that causes respiratory illness. The COVID-19 virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Currently, there is no evidence to show that COVID-19 is spread through food or food packaging.

It is important to always follow general food safety guidelines:

  • Wash your hands with soap and water for 20 seconds before preparing or eating food.

  • Throughout the day, wash your hands after blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing, or going to the bathroom.

It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object, like a package or container, that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

Find shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the FDA and tips on how to handle and prepare food safely from the CDC.

Learn from the CDC how to help prevent spread of the virus and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.
answerText:
According to CDC, although the virus can survive for a short period on some surfaces, it is unlikely to be spread from domestic or international mail, products or packaging.
The COVID-19 virus is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person. It is possible that a person could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or eyes, but this is not thought to be a common way that COVID-19 spreads. This can be prevented by washing your hands before you touch your face, mouth or eyes.
The CDC recommends washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or using a hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol after collecting mail from a post office or home mailbox.

questionOriginal: Do I need to quarantine if I live with someone or had close contact with someone who is under quarantine?
questionText: Do I need to quarantine if I live with someone or had close contact with someone who is under quarantine?
answerOriginal:
No. You do not need to quarantine if you had close contact with someone who is under quarantine. That means you can go to school, work, or the grocery store.

If you are living with someone who is under quarantine, stay at least 6 feet from them. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.

questionOriginal: What is known about the new variants of the COVID-19 virus?
questionText: What is known about the new variants of the COVID-19 virus?
answerOriginal:
Viruses constantly change through mutation, and new variants of a virus are expected to occur over time. Sometimes new variants emerge and disappear. Other times, they emerge and persist. Multiple variants of the virus that causes COVID-19 have been documented in the United States and globally during this pandemic.

According to the CDC, multiple COVID-19 variants are circulating globally, namely in the United Kingdom (UK), South Africa and Brazil. The UK variant, called B.1.1.7, has been detected in numerous countries around the world, including the United States and Canada.

Currently, there is no evidence that these variants cause more severe illness or increased risk of death. These variants seem to spread more easily and quickly than other variants, which may lead to more cases of COVID-19.

Information about the new COVID-19 variants is rapidly emerging. Scientists are working to learn more about how easily they might spread, whether they could cause more severe illness, and whether currently authorized vaccines will protect people against them.

Learn more about what we know, what we donât know, and what the CDC is doing about new COVID-19 variants.
answerText:
Viruses constantly change through mutation, and new variants of a virus are expected to occur over time. Sometimes new variants emerge and disappear. Other times, they emerge and persist. Multiple variants of the virus that causes COVID-19 have been documented in the United States and globally during this pandemic.
According to the CDC, multiple COVID-19 variants are circulating globally, namely in the United Kingdom (UK), South Africa and Brazil.
The UK variant, called B.1.1.7, has been detected in numerous countries around the world. This variant was first detected in the U.S. at the end of December 2020. In January 2021, experts in the UK reported that this variant may be associated with an increased risk of death compared to other variant viruses, but more studies are needed to confirm this finding.
These variants seem to spread more easily and quickly than other variants, which may lead to more cases of COVID-19. An increase in the number of cases will put more strain on health care resources, lead to more hospitalizations, and potentially more deaths. You can find a map showing the number of confirmed cases caused by variants in the U.S.
Information about these variants is rapidly emerging. Scientists are working to learn more about how easily they spread, whether they could cause more severe illness, and whether currently authorized vaccines will protect people against them.
Learn more about what we know, what we donât know, and what the CDC is doing about new COVID-19 variants.

questionOriginal: What is the Health Department doing?
questionText: What is the Health Department doing?
answerOriginal:
The Vermont Department of Health is working closely with long-term care facilities and other group living facilities to prepare for COVID-19 cases and prevent outbreaks, by reviewing CDC guidance for infection control and supporting development of strategies and plans. If cases occur in these settings, the Vermont Department of Health helps the facility implement control measures and prevent additional cases.

The Department does contact tracing to investigate possible travel or exposure history and to identify anyone who had close contact with the person who has tested positive for COVID-19. Those individuals will be assessed for their exposure risk and provided with guidance for their health. Where appropriate, they will receive recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions. Please note, the Health Department only uses a live person for contact tracing and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call.

Find up-to-date information on the Health Department's COVID-19 website.
answerText:
The Health Department has put into place appropriate measures to protect businesses and Health Department staff. Emergencies and foodborne outbreak investigations are still being responded to during the COVID-19 pandemic.
If you have a complaint about a restaurant, you can submit an illness or sanitation complaint online, email FoodLodging@vermont.gov, or call 802-863-7221.
